Americans' views of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats [4]. A substantial majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (82%) believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [10]. This partisan divide is further illustrated by the fact that Republicans are about twice as likely to think China has done a *very* bad job (61% vs. 30%) [10].
![Opinions on the Chinese government’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan.](image1)
The differing perceptions extend to the impact of China's actions on the global spread of the virus. 73% of Republicans believe China's early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, while only 38% of Democrats say the same [5].
![Survey response distributions on the degree of agreement with a statement.](image4)
In terms of U.S.-China relations, Republicans are about twice as likely (71%) as Democrats (37%) to say the U.S. should hold China responsible even at the expense of worse economic relations [9].

In conclusion, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and are more willing to prioritize holding China accountable, even if it damages U.S.-China relations, compared to Democrats.

A significant disparity exists between Republicans and Democrats regarding their views on China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Republicans are much more critical of China's response. A substantial majority (82%) of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China did a bad job, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [10]. This partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that Republicans are about twice as likely to believe China did a *very* bad job (61% vs. 30%) [10].
![Perceptions of "Bad" or "Good" across Demographics](image4)
Furthermore, 73% of Republicans believe that China's initial handling of the outbreak contributed "a great deal" to the global spread, whereas only 38% of Democrats share this view [7]. This difference in opinion is also reflected in the willingness to hold China accountable. 71% of Republicans support holding China responsible even at the expense of worsening economic relations, compared to only 37% of Democrats [3].
![U.S. Public Opinion on U.S.-China Relations and China's Role in the Outbreak](image1)
Perceptions have also become more negative over time, within each party. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, the majority (63%) now believe bilateral economic ties are bad, up by 15-point increase from 2019 [4].
![Change of Bad and Good from 2019 to 2020](image3)
Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents have also become more negative, with 73% saying ties are bad, a 12-point increase from the prior year [4].
![Trend of Group from 2005 to 2020](image2)

In conclusion, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of COVID-19 than Democrats, and both groups have become increasingly negative in their assessments over time.

Americans exhibit a range of views regarding China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and the subsequent impact on U.S.-China relations, with noticeable differences across political affiliations. Many Americans believe that the Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan significantly contributed to the global spread of the virus [1, 9]. Specifically, around three-quarters of Americans acknowledge that China's early actions contributed either a great deal (51%) or a fair amount (27%) to the virus's global spread [4]. This sentiment is visually represented in a bar graph showing these proportions.
![A great deal with 51% of responses, represented by a green segment.](image2)

A significant portion of Americans, 64%, believe that China has done a bad job handling the outbreak [10]. This perception is further broken down demographically, revealing that older individuals and Republicans are more critical of China's response.
![The bars for "Bad" are shown in blue, and the bars for "Good" are shown in green.](image3)
Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely (82%) than Democrats and Democratic leaners (54%) to say China has done a bad job [8, image3].

There are also divided opinions on how the U.S. should respond to China's role in the pandemic. Half of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible, even if it worsens economic relations, while 38% prioritize strong U.S.-China relations [5, 7].
![50% think the U.S. should prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role.](image1)
Republicans are about twice as likely (71%) as Democrats (37%) to say the U.S. should hold China responsible, even at the expense of worsened economic relations [7]. Those who believe China did a poor job handling the outbreak are far more likely (85%) to have an unfavorable view of the country [3].

In conclusion, Americans' views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak are largely negative, with a majority faulting China's initial handling of the situation, and these views differ significantly based on political affiliation, with Republicans being more critical than Democrats.

Americans have increasingly negative views of China, with 73% of U.S. adults holding an unfavorable opinion, a 26-percentage-point increase since 2018 [5]. This sentiment is significantly influenced by the perception that China mishandled the initial outbreak and subsequent spread of COVID-19 [5]. A substantial majority (78%) blame the Chinese government's initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan for the global spread of the virus [7].

This negative perception extends to broader U.S.-China relations, with 68% of Americans saying current economic ties are in bad shape [8]. Americans' views of China have become increasingly negative over time, with significant differences across age groups and political affiliations. Currently, 73% of U.S. adults hold an unfavorable view of China, a 26% increase since 2018 [9].

Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and older, have the most negative views. In this age group, 81% view China unfavorably [3], a substantial increase compared to younger demographics. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to have unfavorable views of China compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (83% vs. 68%, respectively) [6]. Americans across various demographics hold largely unfavorable views of China, with significant differences observable across age groups and political affiliations. Age also plays a significant role. Older Americans (50 and older) are more critical of China's response, with 73% finding fault, compared to 59% of those aged 30 to 49, and 54% of those under 30 [9].

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly shapes views on key foreign policy partners [8]. While both Republicans and Democrats consider the UK their most important partner, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [8]. Democrats, conversely, prioritize Canada and Mexico more than Republicans do [8].

However, views on Germany as a foreign policy partner are similar among both parties, with Germany ranking fifth on the list for both [8]. Democrats are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [3]. When choosing between a close relationship with Russia or Germany, about two-thirds of Democrats (66%) prefer close ties with Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans [4]. Conversely, 31% of Republicans favor close relations with Russia, compared to only 21% of Democrats [4].

In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more inclined toward greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [3]. For Germans across different political affiliations, France is generally named as the most or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. [9].

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence preferences for foreign policy partners and the desired levels of cooperation.

Americans and Germans differ significantly in their preferences for cooperation with Russia and China. Germans are nearly twice as likely as Americans to desire greater collaboration with Russia [3].

In terms of political affiliations influencing these preferences:

*   In the U.S., Republicans (41%) are more inclined than Democrats (32%) to favor increased cooperation with Russia [3].
*    In Germany, 75% of residents in former East Germany compared with 63% in former West Germany, want greater cooperation with Russia [3].
*   When choosing between a close relationship with Russia or Germany, 61% of Americans prefer Germany, while 26% prefer Russia. Among Germans, the preference for the U.S. over Russia is smaller (39% to 25%) [8].
 ! [Americans are more likely to prefer a close relationship with Germany over Russia.](image2)
*   In the U.S., Democrats (75%) show greater willingness for cooperation with Germany than Republicans (63%).
![Political affiliations and cooperation preferences in the U.S. and Germany.](image3)
*   In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU (57%) are more inclined towards greater cooperation with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens (45%) and the SPD (47%) [9].

Regarding China, Germans are about twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%), whereas Americans are almost equally divided, with 41% preferring Germany and 44% preferring China [10].
There are also slight partisan differences exist in the U.S. regarding close relationships with Russia or Germany, with 66% of Democrats preferring close ties with Germany compared to 57% of Republicans [2]. And 31% of Republicans prefer a close relationship with Russia, compared to 21% of Democrats [2].

In conclusion, Germans are more inclined towards cooperation with Russia than Americans, while Americans are more divided on the issue of cooperation with China, showing varying preferences influenced by political affiliation.

In the U.S., Democrats are more inclined to favor cooperation with Germany than Republicans [1, 5]. Specifically, 66% of Democrats prefer close ties with Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans [5]. Conversely, Republicans show a greater preference for close relations with Russia (31%) compared to Democrats (21%) [5]. In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more inclined towards greater cooperation with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and SPD [1].
![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany.](image1)
Attitudes towards cooperation with Russia are also influenced by political affiliation and geographic location. Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. In the U.S., more Republicans (41%) than Democrats (32%) prefer increased cooperation with Russia [3].

Regarding China, Americans are almost equally divided on whether they prefer a close relationship with Germany (41%) or China (44%) [6].
![This image is a bar chart comparing the opinions of Americans and Germans regarding two different questions.](image5)
In conclusion, political party preferences significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with other countries, with Democrats in the U.S. favoring Germany and Republicans leaning more towards Russia, while German CDU/CSU supporters favor the U.S. more than supporters of other parties.

In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [2].
![Political Affiliations in the U.S. and Germany Influence Attitudes Toward Cooperation with Russia](image1)
In Germany, there are regional differences based on historical divisions. Those living in former East Germany are more likely to want greater collaboration with Russia (75%) than those in former West Germany (63%) [2]. There are also slight partisan divisions in the U.S. regarding close ties with Russia or Germany. About two-thirds of Democrats (66%) prefer close ties with Germany, while 57% of Republicans favor the same [4]. In contrast, 31% of Republicans prefer close relations with Russia, compared to 21% of Democrats [4].

The political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with notable differences between Republicans and Democrats in the U.S., and between residents of former East and West Germany.

Americans and Germans have notably divergent views on which country is the world's leading economic power. Half of Americans believe it is the U.S., while a smaller percentage (32%) say it is China [2]. In contrast, a majority of Germans (53%) identify China as the leading economic power, with only 24% naming the U.S. [2]. This difference is visually represented in a bar chart.
![who say __ is the world’s leading economic power](image4)

Regarding international relationships, Germans generally view international organizations and countries more favorably than Americans do [8]. This is particularly evident in the case of the European Union (EU). About seven-in-ten Germans (69%) have a favorable view of the EU, compared to only about half of Americans (51%) [8, image5].
![Approval Ratings of International Entities](image5)
In addition, there are ideological differences within each country.
![Ideological Differences](image1)
There is a difference between German and American perceptions of China, though favorable opinions of China are less widespread in both countries than positive views of the UN and EU [8].
Germans tend to think more highly of China than Americans [image5].

In conclusion, Americans are more likely to view the U.S. as the leading economic power, while Germans are more likely to name China, and Germans generally have more favorable views of international entities like the EU and China compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans have distinct perspectives on international organizations and economic powers, influenced by ideological and regional factors.

Germans generally view international organizations more favorably than Americans do. This is particularly evident in their opinions of the EU, where approximately seven-in-ten Germans hold a favorable view, compared to only about half of Americans [10]. A similar trend is observed with views on Russia, although favorable opinions are less common in both countries than positive views of the UN and EU [10].
![Germans have a more positive view of the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO compared to the U.S.](image1)

The data shows that Germans have a more positive view (+18%) of the EU compared to Americans (69% vs 51%) [image1].
On the topic of the world's leading economic power, Americans and Germans also differ significantly. Half of Americans believe the U.S. is the leading economic power, while a majority of Germans (53%) name China [7].
![Americans are more likely to see the U.S. as the top economic power, while Germans are more likely to name China.](image2)

Ideological differences play a crucial role, particularly in views of the UN, EU, and Russia [9]. In both countries, individuals on the left (liberals in the U.S. and those on the left in Germany) are more likely to favor the UN and EU, while those on the right (conservatives in the U.S. and those on the right in Germany) are more likely to view Russia favorably [3].
![Ideological differences affect views on the UN, EU, and Russia in both the U.S. and Germany.](image4)

In conclusion, Americans and Germans differ in their views of international organizations and economic powers, with Germans generally holding more favorable views of international organizations and differing on which country is the world's leading economic power, influenced by factors such as ideology and regional background.

Americans are more inclined to believe in the necessity of military force, with about 80% agreeing that it is sometimes necessary to maintain world order [4]. In contrast, only about half of Germans share this view [4]. Ideological divides also influence these perceptions; 90% of American conservatives see military force as necessary, compared to 65% of liberals, and in Germany, nearly 60% on the right see it as necessary, while only about a third on the left agree [6].

Regarding defense spending, half of Americans believe that U.S. European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels [1]. Germans are divided, with about 40% favoring maintaining current levels and another 40% advocating for an increase [5].

Despite these differences, younger people in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship [2]. In the U.S., 82% of individuals aged 18 to 29 view the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those aged 65 and older [2]. ![Young people in both countries have the most positive view of U.S.-Germany relationship](image8). Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people consider relations with the U.S. good, while only 31% of those 65 and older agree [2].

In summary, Americans are more likely than Germans to support the use of military force, and there are divisions over defense spending, while younger demographics in both countries view the U.S.-Germany relationship more positively.

Americans and Germans have significantly different views on military intervention and defense spending. For instance, when asked about defending a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, six-in-ten Americans believe their country should intervene, while an equal proportion of Germans believe their country should not [9]. This divergence is visually represented in a chart where 60% of Americans are in favor of intervention ("Should"), contrasting with 60% of Germans who oppose it ("Should not") [1].
![A chart comparing the opinions of people from the U.S. and Germany on an unspecified issue about whether something should or should not be done.](image1)

Regarding the use of military force to maintain order, about eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary, whereas only about half of Germans agree [6]. A bar chart illustrates this difference, showing 78% of Americans agreeing with the use of military force, compared to just 47% of Germans [3].
![A comparative bar chart that depicts the percentage of people in the U.S. and Germany who agree or disagree with an unspecified statement or question.](image3)
Ideological differences within each country also play a role. In the U.S., nine-in-ten conservatives see military force as necessary, compared to 65% of liberals [4].

Regarding defense spending, half of Americans believe that European allies should maintain their current spending levels [2]. However, there's a decreasing trend among Republicans who think European allies should increase their defense budgets, dropping from 62 in 2017 to 48 in 2019 [7].

In contrast, Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain their current defense spending levels [10]. A comparative bar chart depicts these trends over time, showing that in 2019, 40% of Germans supported an increase, while 41% favored maintaining current levels [4].
![comparative bar chart that depicts the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.](image4)

In summary, Americans are more inclined to support military intervention and see it as necessary, while Germans are more hesitant. Regarding defense spending, Americans show a decreasing interest in having European allies increase spending, while Germans are divided on the issue.

Americans' views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of international issues vary significantly across political affiliations and educational backgrounds.

Regarding global engagement, a majority of Republicans (76%) believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [5]. This sentiment is consistent among both conservative and moderate/liberal Republicans [5]. In contrast, a majority of Democrats (53%) believe the U.S. should help other countries, with liberal Democrats (64%) being more supportive of this view than conservative/moderate Democrats (44%) [8].
![Opinions on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries, broken down by political affiliation and other demographics.](image3)

Education also plays a role in these views. Individuals with higher levels of education are more likely to support helping other nations [10]. For instance, 60% of postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while a clear majority of those with a high school diploma or less (69%) think the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [10].

When it comes to handling international issues, such as the coronavirus outbreak, partisan differences are evident. Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the outbreak than Democrats [6]. Specifically, 80% of conservative Republicans believe China has handled the crisis poorly [6].
![Opinions on China's handling of the coronavirus, categorized as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent," across different demographic groups.](image1)
Education level, however, shows little impact of peoples attitude to China [1].

In summary, Republicans and those with less education tend to favor the U.S. focusing on its own problems, while Democrats and those with higher education are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other countries.

Americans' perceptions of how the U.S. and China handled the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly shaped by their political affiliations and educational backgrounds.

There's a wide partisan gap in the evaluation of the U.S. response, with 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praising the country's handling, compared to only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [10]. ![Disparity in opinions between Republicans and Democrats regarding handling of COVID-19.](image2)

Education also plays a role, particularly in evaluating the U.S. response. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree believe the U.S. has done a poor job, a view shared by about six-in-ten college graduates [2].

However, education has little influence on views regarding China's handling of the virus, with majorities across all educational groups stating China has not handled the pandemic well [4]. A significant majority of Americans (nearly two-thirds) believe China did not do a good job managing the outbreak [6]. There are also differences in the view of different age groups. ![Opinions on how China dealt with Covid-19 based on age, education, and party.](image3)

In summary, political affiliation strongly influences perceptions of the U.S. response, while educational background affects the assessment of the U.S. but not China, with widespread agreement across demographics that China handled the pandemic poorly.

Americans are divided along partisan lines in their evaluation of the United States' response to the COVID-19 outbreak [8]. Overall, 47% of adults believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, but this view is held by only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, compared to 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [8].

![Partisan views on the COVID-19 response in the U.S. and other countries.](image2)

There are also significant partisan differences in opinions regarding China's handling of the pandemic [9]. While majorities in both parties believe China has not done a good job, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view than Democrats, with 80% of conservative Republicans saying China has not handled the crisis well [9].

![Evaluation of China's handling of the pandemic by political affiliation.](image3)

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally viewing the U.S. response more favorably and China's response more unfavorably compared to Democrats.

There are significant partisan differences in how much Americans believe the U.S. can learn from the international response to the coronavirus [6]. While a majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (60%) say the U.S. can learn a great deal, only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share that view [6]. This divide is even more pronounced between liberal Democrats (67%) and conservative Republicans (25%) [5].

Views on the World Health Organization (WHO) are also starkly divided along partisan lines [9]. A significant majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (62%) believe the WHO has done at least a good job in handling the global pandemic, whereas only 28% of Republicans and GOP leaners agree [9]. This partisan divide is especially pronounced, with 86% of liberal Democrats trusting information from the WHO at least a fair amount, compared to just 27% of conservative Republicans [10].

Trust in information from the European Union (EU) is relatively high overall but is stronger among those with higher education, which often correlates with political affiliation [3].

In summary, perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus differ significantly between political affiliations, with Democrats more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal compared to Republicans, and these perceptions correlate with higher trust levels in international organizations like the WHO and EU among Democrats.

Americans' views on the future influence of the U.S., the EU, and China vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level.

Regarding China, half of Americans believe its influence will decline post-coronavirus outbreak, while nearly one-in-five think it will grow, and about a third believe its global standing will remain the same [6]. There's a large partisan divide: roughly 60% of Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish, compared to 40% of Democrats [1].
![Opinions on China’s influence after the coronavirus outbreak, categorized by race, age, and political affiliation.](image5)

Concerning the U.S., the American public is largely split [4]. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe U.S. international influence will strengthen [3]. Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken [3]. Education also plays a role, with Americans who have completed higher levels of education being more likely to think the country's global influence will recede [10].
![Opinions on U.S. influence after the coronavirus outbreak, showing categories for education level and political affiliation.](image1)

For the EU, the data provided doesn't offer a breakdown by political affiliation or education level of the view.
![Survey results comparing opinions on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China.](image3)

In summary, Republicans are more optimistic about U.S. influence and more pessimistic about China's compared to Democrats, while higher education levels correlate with a more pessimistic view of future U.S. influence.

Americans' predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly across demographic and political groups.

Regarding the U.S.'s influence, there's a clear partisan divide. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe that U.S. influence will be strengthened [1]. Conversely, Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to foresee a decline in American influence [1]. Educational background also plays a role; Americans with higher education levels are more prone to thinking the country's global influence will decrease [9].
![Predictions for U.S. global influence after coronavirus outbreak based on education level and political affiliation.](image1)

As for China, half of Americans believe its global influence will decline after the outbreak [3], with nearly one-in-five predicting it will grow, and about a third expecting it to remain the same [3]. There are noticeable partisan and age-related differences. Roughly six-in-ten Republicans anticipate a decrease in China's international clout, compared to 40% of Democrats [4]. Older Americans (65+) are also 16 percentage points more likely than younger ones (under 30) to predict a decline in China's global influence [4].
![Predictions for China's global influence after coronavirus outbreak.](image4)

In summary, predictions about global influence after the coronavirus outbreak vary, with Republicans generally more optimistic about U.S. influence and pessimistic about China's, while Democrats and more educated individuals tend to foresee a decline in U.S. influence.

Americans hold a predominantly negative view of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak. Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China has not done a good job, with 37% saying the country has done a "poor" job [3]. This negative perception is further reflected in the belief that the current crisis will have a long-term impact on China’s global stature [9]. Specifically, 50% say China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [9].
![China: Poor (37%), Only fair (26%), Good (26%), Excellent (7%)](image5)

These perceptions are marked by significant partisan differences. Republicans express significantly more negative attitudes toward China than Democrats [4]. While both parties largely agree that China has not handled the outbreak well, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view [7].
![The U.S. should concentrate on its own problems](image4)

This partisan divide extends to views on China's future global influence. Roughly 60% of Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish, compared to just 40% of Democrats [5].
![Less influence (50%), About the same influence (31%), More influence (17%).](image3)

In conclusion, Americans generally view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decline in its global influence, with Republicans holding significantly more negative views than Democrats.

The data indicates significant partisan divisions regarding the U.S.'s role in global affairs and its anticipated influence post-coronavirus outbreak [6]. About six-in-ten Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges, a view shared by only 26% of Democrats [5].

There are also notable differences in how partisans perceive the future of U.S. influence. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe that the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis [10]. Conversely, Democrats are approximately four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken after the outbreak [10]. Within the Democratic Party, liberals are 20 percentage points more likely than conservatives and moderates to predict a decline in U.S. international influence [10, 7]. Specifically, 56% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs, compared to much lower percentages among moderate and liberal Republicans (15%) and conservative Republicans (8%) [7].

In summary, Republicans are more inclined to believe the U.S. does too much globally and will emerge stronger, while Democrats, especially liberal Democrats, are more likely to think the U.S. should do more and will see its influence diminish.

Americans hold varied perspectives on the nation's capacity to learn from international approaches to managing the coronavirus pandemic and its involvement in global affairs. A significant majority believe the U.S. can learn from other countries about slowing the spread of the virus [1, 3, 5, 7].

However, partisan divides are evident in the degree of this belief. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more likely to think the U.S. can learn "a great deal" (60%) compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals (28%) [8].
![Partisan and demographic breakdowns of survey responses regarding amount learned from other countries.](image1)

This partisan difference is further illustrated by the contrast between liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans. While 67% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, only 25% of conservative Republicans hold the same view [4].
![This image is a chart displaying survey data on opinions about the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak and related topics. It shows the responses broken down by political affiliation: Conservative/Moderate or Liberal Republicans (red dots) and Conservative/Moderate or Liberal Democrats (blue dots).](image5)
There are sharp partisan and ideological differences on other questions about foreign policy and international affairs. While 81% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job of dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, just 22% of conservative Republicans say the same [6].

In summary, partisan views differ significantly, with Democrats generally more open to learning from other countries and more inclined to believe the U.S. should play an active role in helping other nations, compared to Republicans.

Americans' views on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or assist other countries vary significantly across political affiliations and educational levels. A majority of Republicans, about 75%, believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [6].

Among Democrats, there's a more divided stance. Slightly more than half believe the U.S. should help other countries, while 46% think the U.S. should focus on its own problems [4]. Ideological differences within the Democratic party further highlight this division: 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [4].

Educational levels also influence these views. Individuals with higher levels of education, are more supportive to help other nations deal with their problems [9]. Six-in-ten postgraduates say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems [9]. College graduates are evenly split on this question, while clear majorities of those with some college experience and those with no more than a high school diploma say the U.S. should deal with its own problems [9].

In summary, views on the U.S. dealing with its problems versus helping other countries differ significantly, with Republicans favoring domestic focus, Democrats being divided with a lean towards helping others (especially among liberal Democrats), and higher education levels correlating with greater support for international assistance.

There are significant differences in how Republicans and Democrats perceive the U.S. role in solving world problems, and these differences have changed considerably over time.

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [3]. This sentiment is visually represented in a line graph showing an increase from 52% in 2013 to 62% in 2020 for the "Too much" category. ![The image is a line graph displaying data from 2013 to 2020. - The green line represents "Too little," beginning at 19% in 2013 and dropping to 8% in 2020.

Each line shows how these opinions have changed over time.](image3) In contrast, only 8% of Republicans think the U.S. does too little, and 29% believe it does the right amount [3]. About three-quarters of Republicans prefer the U.S. to focus on its own problems and let other countries manage themselves [8].

On the other hand, a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems [3]. More than half of Democrats favor the U.S. helping other countries, although there is an ideological divide, with 64% of liberal Democrats supporting this view compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [7].

Overall, 60% of Americans believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems, while 39% believe the U.S. should help other countries [5].

The partisan divide in these views was far less pronounced in previous years than it is today [6].

In conclusion, Republicans predominantly believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, a view that has strengthened over time, while Democrats are more divided, with a significant portion believing the U.S. should do more to help other countries.

There are significant partisan differences in views regarding U.S. global engagement. A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [3]. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems.](image1) Republicans predominantly favor a focus on domestic issues, with about three-quarters advocating for the U.S. to deal with its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [10].

Conversely, a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little to assist in global issues [3]. More than half of Democrats express that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems [5]. However, there is an ideological divide within the Democratic Party, with 64% of liberal Democrats favoring international assistance compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [5].

Educational attainment also influences these perspectives. Individuals with higher levels of education are more supportive of the U.S. helping other nations [6]. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while college graduates are evenly split, and majorities of those with some college or less education believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [6].

In summary, Republicans and those with less education generally prefer the U.S. to focus on domestic issues, while Democrats and those with higher education are more inclined to support U.S. involvement in solving global problems.

Americans have relatively low confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China compared to other foreign policy issues [1, 2]. Only 53% of Americans express confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China, which is the lowest among six foreign policy issues tested [2]. This is visualized in a bar chart showing confidence levels across various issues, where "Dealing effectively with China" has the lowest combined "Somewhat" and "Very" confidence levels.
![Confidence levels in Biden's handling of various foreign policy issues](image1)

In contrast, Americans express substantial concern regarding specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [10]. Many issues, such as cyberattacks, job losses to China, and China's growing military power, have seen increased concern over the past year [9]. A bar chart presents these concerns.
![Seriousness of issues related to China](image4)

Cyberattacks from China are considered a very serious problem by 65% of Americans, and China's growing military power is viewed as very serious by 52% [10]. These concerns highlight specific anxieties within the bilateral relationship. The loss of U.S. jobs to China is also a major concern, with 53% of Americans viewing it as a very serious problem [8, 10].

In summary, Americans have lower confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China compared to other foreign policy matters, while simultaneously viewing specific issues like cyberattacks, military power, and job losses related to China as very serious.

Americans express substantial concern about various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship, with certain issues standing out more prominently [5]. A bar chart highlights these concerns, categorizing them as "Very serious" and "Somewhat serious" [5]. The top concerns include cyberattacks from China, China's growing military power, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, and China's human rights policies [5].

![Concerns about China](image3)

Specifically, 65% of Americans view cyberattacks from China as a "very serious" problem, and 53% say the same about the loss of U.S. jobs to China [5]. China's growing military power and policies on human rights are also considered "very serious" by 52% and 50% of Americans, respectively [5].

Confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic groups.
![Confidence Level of Biden](image2)

Overall, 53% of Americans have confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, while 46% do not. This confidence level, however, is the lowest among six international issues tested [2]. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%) [10]. Additionally, those with a college degree show higher confidence (60%) compared to those without (50%) [10]. There are large partisan differences, with 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents having confidence in Biden on China, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [3].

In summary, the primary concerns Americans have regarding China are cyberattacks, military power, job losses, and human rights, with confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varying significantly across demographic groups, and being lowest among Republicans.

Overall, 53% of Americans have confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, while 46% have no confidence. This confidence varies significantly across different demographic and political groups [3].

*   **Political Affiliation**: There is a large partisan divide. 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents have confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [8].
*   **Ideology within Parties**: Conservative Republicans have even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [4]. Among Democrats, confidence levels are similar between conservatives/moderates (86%) and liberals (81%) [4].
*   **Gender**: Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%) in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China [6].
*   **Race/Ethnicity**: Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%) [6].
*   **Education**: Those with a college degree have higher confidence (60%) compared to those with less schooling (50%) [6].

Cyberattacks from China evoke the most concern, with roughly two-thirds of Americans considering these attacks a very serious problem [7].

Americans perceive China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic negatively, with a majority believing China has done a bad job [7]. Specifically, 54% of Americans think China has done a "bad job," while 43% think it has done a "good job" [image2].
![Perceptions of China and the U.S. handling a situation](image2)

In stark contrast, the perception of China's respect for personal freedoms is overwhelmingly negative. A striking 90% of Americans believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [image1, 6].
![Perceptions of China respecting personal freedoms and U.S. priorities in its relations with China](image1)

As for U.S. priorities in its relations with China, a significant majority of Americans (70%) believe the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights, even if it harms economic relations. Conversely, only 26% think the U.S. should prioritize economic relations at the expense of addressing human rights issues [image1].

Americans believe China handled COVID-19 poorly, overwhelmingly believe China does not respect personal freedoms, and prioritize human rights over economic relations in the U.S.-China relationship.

Americans across the political spectrum show a strong inclination towards prioritizing human rights over economic gains in the U.S.-China relationship. A significant majority of both Democrats and Republicans, around 70%, believe that the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it leads to economic repercussions [6].
