Americans, regardless of political affiliation, overwhelmingly prioritize human rights over economic gains in their relationship with China [7]. Approximately 70% of both Democrats and Republicans believe the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [10]. This sentiment is further broken down within each party:
![The chart shows that the majority of Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, with little variation across political lines.](image1)
Specifically, 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor promoting human rights, with 77% of conservative Republicans and 66% of moderate/liberal Republicans holding this view [image1]. Similarly, 69% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents prioritize human rights, including 64% of conservative/moderate Democrats and 76% of liberal Democrats [image1].

However, views differ significantly when it comes to economic and trade policies. A majority of Americans want the U.S. to get tougher with China on these issues, but this sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans [6].
![The data shows Republicans strongly favor getting tougher with China, while Democrats prefer building a stronger relationship.](image5)
The chart shows that 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaners want to "Get tougher," compared to only 37% of Democrats and Democrat-leaners. Within the Republican party, 81% of conservatives advocate for a tougher stance, while 58% of moderate/liberals agree. Among Democrats, the split is more even, with 38% of conservative/moderate Democrats and 37% of liberal Democrats wanting to get tougher [image5]. Some Americans are concerned about the impact of tariffs, while other express concern about China's human rights record and global influence. [8, 3, 9].

In conclusion, while both Democrats and Republicans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, they diverge on trade policy, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and Democrats leaning towards building a stronger relationship.

Americans hold diverse views on the impact of trade policies with China and the preferred approach to the bilateral relationship, significantly influenced by political affiliation [4, 8].

A majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (72%) believe the U.S. should get tougher with China on economic issues [1]. This sentiment is even stronger among conservative Republicans, with 81% advocating for a tougher stance [1].  ![The chart shows that 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor getting tougher with China on economic issues.](image3)

In contrast, about six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer focusing on building stronger ties with China [1]. This preference is consistent across both liberal and moderate/conservative Democrats [1]. ![Opinions vary across different political groups, with a majority of Democrats and lean Democrats support building a strong relationship.](image3)

Regarding the impact of tariffs, about half of Republicans believe increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were good for the U.S., a view especially strong among conservative Republicans [2]. Democrats, however, mostly say the tariffs were bad for the U.S. [2]. ![The chart shows that 51% of Republicans and Republican-leaning believe it is good for the U.S.](image5)

However, a significant portion of the public (44%) believes that increased tariffs on goods from foreign countries, including China, were ultimately bad for the U.S., compared to 30% who think they were good [5]. ![44% of respondents believe that increased tariffs on goods were bad for the U.S.](image4)

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences views on U.S.-China trade policies, with Republicans generally favoring a tougher stance and Democrats preferring to build a stronger relationship, reflecting differing opinions on the impact of tariffs.

Americans have different perspectives on tariffs and international students based on their political affiliations.

When it comes to tariffs on goods from foreign countries, including China, Republicans are more likely to view them positively [1]. About half of Republicans believe these tariffs are good for the U.S., with conservative Republicans holding this view even more strongly [10]. Democrats, conversely, tend to see the tariffs as detrimental to the U.S. [10].
![Opinions on whether tariffs are good or bad for the US, by political affiliation.](image3)

In terms of personal impact, a majority of people, regardless of income or location, say the tariffs have had no real effect on them [6]. However, when considering the overall effect on the country, more Americans believe the tariffs were ultimately bad (44%) than good (30%) [6].
![Comparison of the perceived impact of tariffs on the U.S. versus personal impact.](image4)

Regarding international students, a large majority of Americans (80%) believe it is good for U.S. colleges and universities to accept them [7].
![Public opinion on whether accepting international students is good or bad, by demographic groups.](image1)
However, there's a partisan divide, with 92% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents viewing international students positively, compared to 67% of Republicans and Republican leaners [2].

When it comes to Chinese students specifically, a majority of Americans (55%) support limiting their numbers in the U.S. [8]. This support is stronger among Republicans (69%) compared to Democrats (42%) [8].
![Opinions on limiting Chinese students in the U.S., categorized by various demographics.](image5)

In conclusion, Republicans generally view tariffs positively and are more supportive of limiting Chinese students, while Democrats generally view tariffs negatively and are more welcoming of international students, including those from China.

Americans show notable divisions in their opinions about limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities, and these divisions are strongly correlated with both age and political affiliation [7]. A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S. [6].

Older Americans are far more likely to support restrictions. Roughly seven-in-ten Americans aged 50 and older favor limiting Chinese students, while those aged 30 to 49 are evenly split, and nearly two-thirds of those aged 18 to 29 oppose the idea [3]. This trend is visually supported by the data.
![Opinions on limiting Chinese students, categorized by age.](image4)

Political affiliation also plays a significant role. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor limitations [3]. Specifically, 69% of Republicans and those leaning Republican support restrictions, compared to 42% of Democrats and those leaning Democrat [9, image4]. One person commented, “We rely TOO MUCH on goods from China. China is trying to dominate the whole world and we are supporting that with the stuff we buy from them. Too bad their scientists seem to be smarter than ours. And they are welcomed here as students. We have to stop kissing up to China.” [2].

These views correlate with confidence levels in Chinese leadership. Older Americans and Republicans, who are more likely to support limiting Chinese students, also express lower confidence in Chinese President Xi Jinping [1, 10].
![Levels of confidence in Xi, categorized by age and political affiliation.](image1)

Older individuals (65 and older) show the highest levels of "no confidence at all" in Xi (53%), while younger individuals (18 to 29) show considerably less (35%) [10]. Similarly, Republicans and those leaning Republican express significantly more "no confidence at all" compared to Democrats and those leaning Democrat [image1].

In conclusion, opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly by age and political affiliation, with older Americans and Republicans more likely to support restrictions, which correlates with lower confidence in Chinese leadership.

American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative between 2018 and 2021. The share of Americans who feel "cold" toward China rose from 46% in 2018 to 67% in 2021 [8]. This shift is visually represented in survey data, showing a marked increase in negative sentiment across all demographics.
![Line graphs showing an increase in negative sentiment toward China from 2018 to 2021](image2)
This trend is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with 79% feeling "cold" toward China in 2021, up from 57% in 2018. Democrats also showed an increase, though less dramatic, from 38% to 61% over the same period [7].

Several key concerns drive these increasingly negative perceptions. A significant factor is China's human rights record, with one-in-five Americans mentioning human rights concerns when asked about China [10], and half of Americans viewing China's human rights policies as a very serious problem for the U.S. [6]. Some Americans specifically highlighted the treatment of Uyghurs, which has been labeled a "genocide" [1, 10].
![Chart showing human rights as a major concern](image3)
The majority of Americans (70%) believe that promoting human rights in China should be prioritized, even if it harms economic relations, highlighting the importance placed on this issue.
![Prioritize human rights over economic relations](image1)
Economic relations between the U.S. and China are also viewed negatively, with 64% of Americans describing them as "somewhat or very bad" [9]. Besides that, many specific concerns related to China including cyberattacks, job losses to China, and China’s growing technological power [6].

In conclusion, American perceptions of China have worsened considerably between 2018 and 2021, driven primarily by concerns over human rights, economic issues, and China's growing power and influence.

Americans have several specific concerns regarding China, with many of these concerns intensifying between 2020 and 2021. Key issues include cyberattacks from China, China's policies on human rights, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, and China's growing military and technological power [9, 10].

The concern over cyberattacks from China increased from 58% in 2020 to 65% in 2021. Similarly, worries about China's human rights policies rose from 43% to 50% during the same period [10]. Concerns about the loss of U.S. jobs to China also grew, moving from 47% in 2020 to 53% in 2021. Additionally, anxieties regarding China's growing military power increased from 46% to 52%, and those about its technological advancements went from 41% to 47% [10].
![Changes in American Concerns about China from 2020 to 2021](image1)

These issues are considered very serious problems for the U.S., reflecting a broader negative sentiment towards China’s influence and policies [9]. Public opinion also reflects a significant partisan divide, with Republicans generally more likely to express stronger negative views and support tougher policies against China [6].
![Polarized Views on China Relations](image5)

The trend shows an increasing apprehension towards China's actions and policies among Americans across various issues [3].

In summary, the key concerns of Americans regarding China include cyberattacks, human rights policies, job losses to China, and China's growing military and technological power, with these concerns notably increasing between 2020 and 2021.

Financial optimism among Latinos has significantly increased since 2008, outpacing the general population [9, 10]. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve ("a lot" or "some") rose by 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015 [9]. In contrast, the general population's optimism increased by only 6 percentage points during the same period, reaching 61% in 2015 [9].

![Comparison of Financial Optimism between General Population and All Hispanics from 2008 to 2015](image3)

This upward trend is visible across various demographic subgroups within the Latino community. For instance, both U.S.-born and foreign-born Hispanics exhibited a 14-percentage point increase in optimism, both reaching 81% in 2015 [6].
![Changes in Financial Optimism Among Hispanic Subgroups from 2008 to 2015](image1)

Optimism levels vary across different age groups. Younger Hispanics (18-29) show the highest expectation for financial improvement, with a 13-percentage point increase from 77% to 90% [image1]. While those 65 and older are less optimistic than younger groups [7], they too experienced an increase in optimism, from 52% to 59% [image1].

Education levels also play a role. Latinos with some college education experienced a 20-percentage point increase in economic optimism, compared to those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [2].

In Summary, financial optimism among Hispanics has increased significantly across all subgroups between 2008 and 2015, exceeding the growth in optimism observed in the general population.

Hispanics' expectations for their children's financial futures are influenced by both their current financial situations and educational attainment.

A majority of Hispanic adults (72%) believe their children will be better off financially than they are [2, 6]. This optimism is visualized in a bar chart showing that across various demographics, a large percentage of Hispanics anticipate a "better off" financial future for their offspring.
![A significant proportion of surveyed Hispanics believe they are economically better off than before, with variations across different demographics.](image5)

However, current financial conditions do play a role in these expectations. Those who rate their current financial situation as "excellent" or "good" are more optimistic about improvements in the coming year.
![The image is a segmented bar chart that illustrates people's expectations about how their financial conditions will change based on their current financial situation.](image2)
Hispanics with a positive view of their current finances are more likely to believe their family's finances will improve [3, 4].

Educational attainment also shows variations in expectations [5]. While a majority across all educational levels expect their children to be better off, high school graduates (79%) are more optimistic than those with some college experience (69%) [5].

In conclusion, while a majority of Hispanics are optimistic about their children's financial future, those with better current financial situations and those who are high school graduates express the highest levels of optimism.

Latinos have consistently shown a more optimistic outlook regarding their financial well-being, even while facing higher unemployment rates compared to non-Hispanics.

From 2004 to 2015, the percentage of Latinos who expected their family finances to improve was consistently higher than that of the general public. Specifically, in 2015, 81% of Latinos held this optimistic view, compared to 61% of the general public [4]. This optimism among Latinos has risen faster than in the general population [7].
![Line graph representing Hispanic and general public opinions](image4)
In addtion, 72% of Latino adults expect their children will be better off financially than they are [3, 5].
![Pie chart of well being](image2)

However, this positive outlook contrasts with the unemployment trends during the same period. The unemployment rate for Latinos has been consistently higher than that for non-Hispanics from 2000 to 2015 [6].
![Line graph of the unemployment rates for Hispanics and non-Hispanics.](image5)
While the Latino unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in 2015, it remained above its 2006 low of 5% [6]. Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, with a median income of $42,491 in 2014 [1].
![Income, poverty and wealth of U.S. Latinos](image1)

In summary, despite facing higher unemployment rates and economic challenges, Latinos have maintained a significantly more optimistic view of their financial well-being and future prospects compared to the general population from 2000 to 2015.

The unemployment rate for Hispanics has improved since the Great Recession, dropping from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [6]. However, it still remains above its low of 5% in the fourth quarter of 2006 and is higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [6]. This trend is visually represented in a graph showing the quarterly unemployment rates for both groups from 2000 to 2015, with Hispanic rates consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the period. ![The image is a line graph showing the quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015.](image5)

Despite the higher unemployment rates, Hispanics remain upbeat about national economic conditions [9]. In a December 2015 survey, 35% of Hispanics said economic conditions today are good or excellent, a higher share than among whites (25%) [9]. Another graph illustrates that Hispanic opinions or attitudes have remained generally higher and increased to a greater extent than the general public's over the period from 2004 to 2015. ![The image is a line graph comparing the attitudes or opinions of Hispanic individuals and the general public from 2004 to 2015.](image4)

However, these positive perceptions contrast with the economic realities faced by many Hispanic households. Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014 [3]. The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, less than a peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [3]. Disparities are evident when compared to the broader U.S. population in terms of income, poverty rate, and wealth. ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image2)

In summary, while Hispanics have a more positive outlook on the economy and have seen improvements in unemployment rates, they still face higher unemployment and greater income and wealth disparities compared to non-Hispanic populations.

The economic challenges faced by Hispanic households present a complex picture when compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015.

In terms of unemployment, the Hispanic community's rate has improved since the Great Recession, dropping from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [1]. However, it remains above its pre-recession low of 5% in the fourth quarter of 2006 and is consistently higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [1]. The trend over time can be seen visually, with Hispanic unemployment rates consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the 2000-2015 period. ![The line graph shows fluctuations in unemployment rates, with Hispanic rates consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the period.](image5)

Regarding median household income, Hispanic households experienced stagnation since the Great Recession, with a median income of $42,491 in 2014, a level essentially unchanged [7]. The median income for Hispanic households in 2014 ($42,500) was notably lower than that of all U.S. households ($53,700). ![The graph shows median household income trends for Hispanic households versus all U.S. households.](image2)

The poverty rate for Hispanic households was 23.6% in 2014, lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [7]. This rate is significantly higher than the 14.8% poverty rate for all U.S. households in the same year. ![This graph represents the poverty rates of Hispanic households compared to all U.S. households.](image2)

Concerning wealth, Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009 of any major racial or ethnic group, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [7]. In 2013, the median wealth for Hispanic households was $13,700, significantly lower than the $81,400 for all U.S. households, and less than in 2005. ![The graph illustrates the disparity in median household wealth between Hispanic households and all U.S. households.](image2)

In summary, from 2000 to 2015, Hispanic households faced greater economic challenges than U.S. households overall, with higher unemployment rates, lower median income, higher poverty rates, and significantly lower median wealth.

Latinos' perceptions of their economic well-being have generally increased between 2008 and 2015 [1]. Most key Latino demographic subgroups reported gains in personal finance ratings since 2008 [7, 8].

![Perceptions of family income vs. cost of living among different ethnic groups in 2014 and 2015.](image1)

In 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos reported that their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living, while 37% said their income was staying about even, and 10% said it was going up faster than the cost of living [3]. The views of Blacks and Whites on this issue were similar to those of Hispanics in 2015 [3]. Between 2014 and 2015, Hispanic views of family income in relation to the cost of living were unchanged [4]. Many Hispanics reported that their family income was falling behind the cost of living in surveys conducted in 2014 and 2015 [5].

![Increase in Latino support or approval ratings across various demographic groups from 2008 to 2015.](image3)

Significant gains were recorded among most demographic subgroups [10]. For instance, positive views of economic well-being rose by 16 percentage points among Latino men and 18 points among Latina women [10].
Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004 [9].

![Trends in the views of Hispanics and the General public from 2004 to 2015.](image2)

From 2008 to 2015, perceptions of personal financial situations and family income relative to the cost of living among Latino groups have improved, with notable gains across most demographic subgroups.

Internet usage among seniors is notably lower than that of the general adult population. While 86% of all adults use the internet, only 59% of adults aged 65 and older do so [5, 9]. This disparity is also evident in broadband adoption, with 70% of all adults having broadband at home compared to 47% of seniors [5].

![Technology adoption rates are lower for those 65 and older compared to all adults.](image5)

Device ownership also differs significantly between the two groups.
![Smartphone and tablet ownership rates are lower for those aged 65 and over compared to all adults.](image3)

Smartphone ownership is much lower among seniors. Only 18% of adults aged 65 and older own a smartphone, compared to 55% of all adults [2]. However, tablet and e-reader ownership is relatively higher among seniors, with 27% owning such devices.

Despite lower overall internet usage, seniors who do go online tend to make it a part of their daily routine [4, 8].
![A significant majority of seniors who use the internet do so daily or almost daily.](image1)

Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [4, 8]. This trend is even more pronounced among seniors with a smartphone or home broadband connection, with 78% of older broadband users and 84% of older smartphone owners going online almost daily [8]. Internet use and broadband adoption decrease from approximately age 75 [5].

![Internet use and broadband at home decreases with age.](image2)

In summary, internet usage and device ownership, especially smartphones, are lower among seniors compared to the general adult population, but those seniors who are online tend to use the internet frequently, often daily.

Internet usage among older adults has been steadily increasing. In 2013, 59% of seniors reported using the internet, a six percentage point increase from the previous year and a significant jump from 35% in 2008 [3].
![Internet adoption over time.](image1)
Despite this growth, internet usage among seniors still trails the overall population, with 86% of all U.S. adults going online [3].

Device ownership among older adults differs from the general population [9]. While more than half of all Americans have a smartphone, only 18% of older adults do [5]. Interestingly, among the senior population, tablets and e-book readers are as popular as smartphones. 27% of seniors own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [7].
![Device ownership by age group.](image4)
Even with lower device ownership rates, a large majority of older adults who use the internet do so frequently. Among those who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [10].

![Frequency of internet use by age group.](image2)
A pie chart shows that 41% of older adults do not go online and 27% using social media.
![Breakdown of online usage among older adults.](image3)
In conclusion, device ownership, particularly of smartphones, is lower among older adults compared to the general population, but those seniors who do go online tend to use the internet very frequently.

Internet usage among seniors has significantly increased over time. In 2000, only about 14% of seniors were online, but by 2013, this number had risen to 59% [4]. This trend is visualized in a line graph showing the growth of internet adoption for both seniors and all adults over time, with seniors consistently trailing behind the general adult population but still showing substantial growth ![Trends of Internet adoption from 2000 to 2013](image4). Overall, 86% of all U.S. adults now go online, a substantially larger proportion than the 59% of seniors who do so [4].

Device ownership also varies considerably between the two groups. While 55% of all adults own a smartphone, only 18% of seniors do. Conversely, tablet and e-reader ownership is higher among seniors (27%) compared to the general adult population (43%) [5].
![Device ownership percentages for all adults vs. seniors aged 65+](image3).

In terms of online activities, a smaller percentage of seniors engage in social networking. A pie chart shows that 27% of older adults use social networking sites (SNS) ![Percentage of older adults who use social networking sites](image2).

Specific demographic factors influence internet and broadband adoption among seniors. For instance, internet usage and broadband adoption rates decrease significantly with age. Among those aged 65-69, 74% go online and 65% have broadband at home. These percentages drop sharply for those aged 80 and older, with only 37% going online and 21% having broadband [3].
![Internet adoption rates by age group](image1).
Education and income also play a critical role. Seniors with a college degree have much higher rates of internet usage (87%) and broadband adoption (76%) compared to those with a high school education or less (40% and 27%, respectively). Similarly, seniors with household incomes of $75,000 or more have high adoption rates (90% online, 82% broadband), while those earning less than $30,000 have much lower rates (39% online, 25% broadband) [3].
![Internet and broadband adoption based on education and income levels](image1).

In summary, while internet adoption among seniors has grown significantly over the years, it still lags behind the general adult population, with significant variations based on age, education, and income, and device ownership differs notably, especially in smartphone usage.

Internet usage among seniors has been steadily increasing, with 59% reporting online usage in recent data [2]. A visual representation of online usage among seniors shows that 27% use Social Networking Services (SNS) [7].
![The pie chart visually represents the percentage of each category.](image2)
Device ownership plays a significant role in these trends. While smartphone ownership among seniors is relatively low (18%), the ownership of tablets or e-readers is higher, at 27% [10].
![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of ownership of smartphones and tablets or e-readers among two groups: all adults and people aged 65 and over. ](image1)
This suggests that a significant portion of seniors are engaging with digital content, though not necessarily through smartphones.
Among seniors who do go online, a notable 46% (representing 27% of the total older adult population) use social networking sites such as Facebook [4]. This indicates that while overall internet usage among seniors trails the general population, those who are online are embracing social networking.

In summary, while overall internet usage rates among seniors are lower than the national average, a significant percentage are online and using social networks, with tablet and e-reader ownership exceeding smartphone ownership.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults show significant variation based on age, education, and income. These rates also generally trail behind those of the general adult population [2].

As age increases, both internet and broadband usage decrease dramatically. For instance, 74% of individuals aged 65-69 go online, compared to only 37% of those aged 80 and older [5]. A similar trend is observed with broadband adoption, with 65% of the 65-69 age group having broadband at home, compared to just 21% of those 80 and older [5].
![Internet and Broadband Usage Among Seniors by Age, Education, and Income](image5)

Education plays a crucial role in technology adoption among seniors. 87% of seniors who are college graduates go online, and 76% have broadband at home [5]. These rates are substantially higher than those for seniors with a high school education or less, where only 40% go online and 27% have broadband [5].

Household income is also a strong indicator of internet and broadband adoption. Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online, and 82% have broadband [5]. In contrast, among those earning less than $30,000 per year, only 39% go online, and 25% have broadband [5].

Younger, more affluent, and better-educated seniors show adoption rates closer to the general population [8].
![Internet Usage Trends Over Time (2000-2013): All Adults vs. Seniors (65+)](image4)
Despite the increasing adoption rates, seniors still lag behind the general population. As of the data provided, 59% of seniors use the internet, compared to 86% of all U.S. adults [2]. The graph shows a consistent gap between the two groups over time [4].

In summary, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are significantly influenced by age, education, and income, with usage sharply declining among older, less educated, and lower-income seniors, and these rates are generally lower than those for the overall adult population.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors show significant variation based on income and education levels. Seniors with higher incomes and more education exhibit usage rates closer to the general population. For instance, among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home [9]. Similarly, 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters [7, 9].
![Percentage of 65+ who go online and have broadband](image3)

In contrast, seniors with lower incomes or less education have much lower adoption rates. Only 39% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually go online, and just 25% have broadband at home [9]. Among seniors who have not attended college, 40% go online, and only 27% have broadband at home [9].

Cell phone ownership is prevalent among seniors, with 77% owning one [4]. However, smartphone adoption is much lower, at just 18% [10].
![Smartphone, tablet, or e-reader ownership rates for adults and seniors](image1)
These rates also vary significantly by income and education, following a similar pattern to internet and broadband adoption. As shown in the table, cell phone and smartphone ownership are more common among wealthier and college-educated seniors.
![Cell phone ownership rates by demographic](image5)
In summary, internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors are significantly higher for those with greater income and education levels, while those with lower income and less education have substantially lower rates.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) show significant variations based on income and education levels, mirroring trends observed in the broader population but at generally lower adoption rates.

As of the data collected, 59% of seniors report going online, and 47% have a high-speed broadband connection at home [9]. This is detailed further by income and education levels:
- **Household Income**: Seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more have a 90% online usage rate and 82% broadband adoption rate. In contrast, those with an income of less than $30,000 have only a 39% online usage rate and a 25% broadband adoption rate [5].
![Data table showing how older adults' internet and broadband usage varies by age, education, and income.](image5)
- **Education**: 87% of seniors who are college graduates go online, with 76% having broadband at home. This contrasts sharply with seniors who have a high school education or less, where only 40% go online and 27% have broadband [5].

Smartphone ownership also reflects these disparities:
- **Overall Adoption**: Only 18% of seniors own a smartphone [9].
- **Income Disparity**: 42% of seniors with an income of $75,000 or more own smartphones, compared to just 8% of those earning less than $30,000 [4].
- **Educational Influence**: 35% of college-educated seniors own smartphones, compared to 10% of those with a high school education or less [4].
![Data table showing how older adults' cell phone and smartphone ownership varies by age, education, and income.](image4)

These adoption rates are significantly lower than the national averages, where 91% of all Americans own a cell phone, and smartphone adoption is above 55% [4, 10]. Affluent and well-educated seniors tend to adopt technology at higher rates than their peers with lower income and educational levels [1]. For instance, there is a substantial difference between the adoption of e-book readers and tablets by income with 33% of the people in the $50,000-74,999 adopting e-book readers.
![Data table showing how older adults' ownership of e-book readers and tablet computers varies by age, education, and income.](image1)
However, subgroups like those 80 years or older, those with low household incomes, and those who have not attended college are much more removed from online life [3].

In conclusion, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly influenced by income and education, with higher income and education correlating with higher adoption rates, though these remain below the national averages for all adults.

Technology adoption, including internet usage and smartphone ownership, varies significantly among seniors based on their educational backgrounds.

Generally, seniors with higher educational attainment exhibit higher rates of both internet usage and smartphone ownership. College graduates show the highest adoption rates. Specifically, 87% of seniors who are college graduates go online, and 76% have broadband at home [2]. 35% of senior who are college graduate own a smartphone [5].
![Percentages of seniors (65+) who go online and have broadband, categorized by education.](image2)
In contrast, seniors with a high school education or less have much lower rates. Among this group, only 40% go online, and 27% have broadband at home [2, 7]. Only 10% of seniors with high school grad or less are smartphone owners [5]. Those with some college education fall in between these two extremes, the internet usage and broadband adoption is 69% and 57% [7]. And 19% of seniors with some college education are smartphone owners [5].

![Percentages of seniors (65+) who own cell phones and smartphones, categorized by education.](image5)

In summary, internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors increase significantly with higher educational attainment.

Among seniors aged 65 and older, internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership, vary significantly based on education and income levels.

For internet and broadband adoption, college graduates show significantly higher rates compared to those with a high school education or less. Specifically, 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% have broadband at home [3]. In contrast, only 40% of seniors who have not attended college go online, and just 27% have broadband [3].
![Percentages of seniors (65+) online and with broadband by education and income.](image3)

Income also plays a crucial role. Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home [3]. However, for seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online and 25% have broadband at home [3].
![Internet usage trends for all adults vs seniors (65+).](image1)

Regarding cell phone and smartphone ownership, a similar trend is observed. 87% of seniors with a college degree own cell phones, and 35% own smartphones [2]. Seniors with high school grad or less, these figures drop to 70% for cell phone ownership and a mere 10% for smartphone ownership [2].
![Percentages of seniors owning cell phones and smartphones by education and income.](image2)

Income disparities are equally striking. 92% of seniors with an income of $75,000 or more own cell phones, and 42% own smartphones [2]. Among seniors with an income of less than $30,000, cell phone ownership is at 67%, and smartphone ownership is at 8% [2]. Even the most affluent seniors trail the general population in smartphone adoption, with 42% ownership compared to 76% of high-income adults in the general population [2].

In summary, higher education and income levels are strongly correlated with higher rates of internet use, broadband adoption, and ownership of cell phones and smartphones among seniors.

Broadband adoption among seniors varies significantly based on both educational attainment and household income. Seniors with higher education levels show much higher rates of broadband adoption. For instance, 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% of them are broadband adopters [2]. In contrast, among seniors who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and a mere 27% have broadband at home [10].
![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image2)

Similarly, household income plays a crucial role in broadband adoption rates among seniors. For those with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home [10]. However, for seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online and 25% have broadband at home [10]. This demonstrates a clear trend where higher income correlates with higher broadband adoption rates among seniors.

In summary, broadband adoption at home among seniors is significantly higher for those with higher educational attainment and higher household income.

Tablet and e-book reader adoption among seniors is significantly influenced by education level [4, 10]. Seniors who have graduated from college are approximately three times more likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to seniors who have not attended college [4]. Specifically, 30% of college-graduate seniors own e-book readers, and 31% own tablets, while only 12% of seniors with a high school education or less own e-book readers, and 11% own tablets [!['The table compares the percentage of people aged 65 and older who use e-book readers and tablet computers, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image3)].

This trend contrasts with the general adoption of technology across different age groups over time, where younger age groups consistently show higher usage rates. For instance, technology adoption has been increasing across all age groups, with the 18-29 age group reaching 90% by 2013, and the 65+ age group, while showing the lowest initial usage, climbed consistently to 46% by 2013 [!['The image is a line graph showing the percentage of people in different age groups using some form of technology or service over time, from 2006 to 2013. The graph is broken down into four age groups: 18-29, 30-49, 50-64, and 65+. '](image4)].

Education level significantly impacts the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, with higher education correlating with higher adoption rates, unlike the broader trend where younger age groups generally show higher technology adoption rates regardless of education.

Workforce technologies' impact on employees is significantly influenced by their educational attainment. Individuals with higher levels of education tend to view these technologies more positively. For instance, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [10]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their career opportunities, while only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less share the same view [7, 10].

![College graduates are more likely to believe technology increased opportunities and made work more interesting.](image1)

This disparity is further evidenced by the fact that many workers with high school diplomas or less do not perceive technology as a positive force that enhances their work or provides career advancement [6, 7].

The general sentiment on how these technologies affect various aspects of works. A significant number of workers feel that the technologies like word processing(70%) , smartphones(67%), and email or social media(60%) have postive impacted on their own careers [4, 9].

![Technologies like word processing, smartphones, and email have largely impacted workers positively.](image4)

Regarding future technologies, there's considerable awareness and anticipation surrounding driverless vehicles [2]. The expectation is that driverless vehicle technology will make significant advancements in the coming decades [3]. A substantial majority (56%) of Americans anticipate that most vehicles will be driverless within the next 10 to 50 years [2].

![Most Americans believe driverless cars will be common within 50 years.](image2)

In conclusion, educational attainment significantly shapes perceptions of workforce technologies, with higher education correlating with more positive views, and there's a broad expectation that driverless cars will become widespread within the next 50 years.

Americans have a broad awareness of the efforts to develop driverless vehicles, with 94% having some knowledge of this. A significant portion, approximately two-thirds of the public, anticipate that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next 50 years, and 9% predict this will happen within the next 10 years [1].

Workers' perceptions of technology's impact in the workplace vary significantly based on educational attainment. Workers with at least a four-year college degree generally have more positive views compared to those with a high school diploma or less [4]. The differences are most pronounced with office productivity tools, such as word processing or spreadsheet software. There is a 45-percentage-point difference between college graduates (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) who believe these technologies have positively impacted them professionally [4].

Differences of 20 percentage points or more also exist between these groups for other technologies, including email or social media (27 points), smartphones (22 points), and software that manages workers’ daily schedules and routines (21 points) [4]. In total, nearly one-quarter (24%) of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of these technologies has had a positive impact on their jobs or careers; for college graduates, that figure is just 2% [4]. Roughly half of workers (53%) feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting [9].

In summary, perceptions of workplace technology's impact vary significantly by education level, with college graduates generally having a more positive outlook than those with a high school diploma or less, and there is widespread awareness and anticipation for the adoption of driverless cars in the future.

Many Americans anticipate significant changes from automation technologies, including the widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles [5]. Approximately two-thirds of the public expects most vehicles on the road to be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting this will occur in the next 10 years [6].
![In less than 50 years, most people anticipate that vehicles will be driverless.](image2)

In contrast, U.S. workers today express mixed views on the impact of current technologies on their jobs and careers [2]. Many workers view technologies like word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) as having a positive impact [4].
![This is a bar chart showing the perceived impact of various technologies.](image1)
However, a substantial number see these technologies as damaging or neutral to their career prospects [1]. For example, While 46% of workers feel that technology has increased their career opportunities, 13% believe it has decreased their opportunities, and 40% see no impact [7].
![_A chart shows 13% of people felt technology decreased opportunities, 46% felt it increased opportunities, and 40% felt no impact._](image4)
Roughly half of the workers (53%) feel that technology has made their work more interesting. [7].
![_A bar graph shows that 53% of workers thought technology made work more interesting._](image5)

The perceptions of automation and workforce technology differ significantly. Future expectations for driverless vehicles are largely anticipatory and focused on widespread societal change, whereas current experiences with technology reflect a mix of positive, negative, and neutral impacts on individual workers' careers.

Workers' perceptions of workplace technologies vary significantly based on their educational attainment, especially regarding job interest and career opportunities [1], [7].

Generally, workers with at least a four-year college degree view the impact of technology on their work more positively than those with high school diplomas or less [9]. Specifically, college graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting.
![The image is a bar chart comparing the effects of education level on work factors.](image3)
There is a 45-percentage point difference between workers with a college degree (90%) and workers with high school diploma or less (45%) who feel that office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact on them professionally [9].
![The image is a bar chart that shows the perceived impact of various technologies on different educational groups.](image4)
College graduates are also more inclined to believe that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement [2], [3].
![The image is a bar graph showing responses to a survey question.](image2)
In contrast, workers with high school diplomas or less are more subdued about technology's impact. Only 38% believe technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% feel it has increased their career advancement opportunities [10].

Workers with some college education but without a four-year degree usually hold views that fall between these two groups [4]. A plurality of workers (46%) feel that technology has enhanced their opportunities for career growth, yet 13% believe it has diminished these opportunities, and 40% see no significant impact [5].
![The image is a bar chart showing the effects on opportunities.](image1)

In conclusion, perceptions of workplace technologies vary significantly by education level, with college graduates generally having a more positive outlook on technology's impact on job interest and career opportunities compared to those with less education.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment express significantly different views on workplace technology [3]. Specifically, college graduates are more likely to report that technology has positively impacted their careers [7, 8].

For instance, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [1]. This disparity is visually represented in a comparison of educational levels on work factors:
![Educational levels impact whether work is more interesting](image5)

Similarly, technology's role in career advancement is viewed differently across educational groups. 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, while only 32% of workers with high school diplomas or less share this view [1, 2].

The perceived impact extends to specific technologies as well. For example, 90% of college graduates view word processing or spreadsheet software positively, compared to 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [9]. The following chart illustrates this:
![positive and negative effect of technologies](image3)

In summary, educational attainment significantly influences how workers perceive technology's impact on their jobs, with higher education levels correlating with more positive views on technology's role in making work more interesting and increasing advancement opportunities.

Workers with higher levels of education generally have more positive views of workplace technologies [6, 8]. Specifically, college graduates are more likely to report that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement. For example, 53% of college graduates versus 32% of those with a high school diploma or less say technology increased their job opportunities [9].

![Perceived Impact of Technology on Career Opportunities by Education Level](image3)

In addition, college graduates are more likely to find that technology made their work more interesting [9]. The image shows that 64% of college graduates agreed with this statement, compared to 38% of high school graduates or less. A significant percentage of workers with high school diplomas or less indicate that these technologies have not impacted their careers in any meaningful way [7].

![Perceived Impact of Various Technologies on Workers by Education Level](image1)

The bar chart shows the perceived impact of various technologies, broken down by educational attainment. For every technology listed, college graduates (College grad+) have a higher percentage of positive impact compared to those with some college or a high school education or less (HS or less). For instance, 90% of college graduates reported a positive impact from word processing or spreadsheet software, compared to 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [10].

In conclusion, educational levels significantly impact perceptions of technology's effects, with higher education correlating with more positive views on job opportunities and work interest.

Americans' familiarity with the concept of machines taking over human jobs significantly shapes their views, though concern remains consistently high across all levels of awareness. Those who have heard a lot about this concept are more likely to find it realistic and express enthusiasm, but they are just as worried as those with less awareness [6].

Specifically, 47% of those who have heard a lot about the concept are very or somewhat enthusiastic about it, compared to 30% who have heard a little and 18% who have heard nothing [3].
![Survey responses about the concept of machines taking over human jobs.](image3)

However, worry remains high across the board. 76% of those who have heard a lot express some level of worry, which is similar to the 72% who have heard a little and the 69% who have heard nothing [9].
![Feelings of Enthusiasm and Worry.](image1)

The public generally anticipates more negative than positive outcomes from widespread automation [5]. A significant majority (76%) expect increased inequality between the rich and poor [8], and 64% believe people will struggle to find meaningful activities [10].
![Likelihood of various automation outcomes.](image4)

Only 25% expect the creation of many new, better-paying jobs for humans [1, 8]. Many Americans would favor policy to mitigate these risks, the most popular is that robots and computers be mostly limited to doing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [2].
![Public opinion on automation policies.](image2)

In conclusion, Americans' awareness of automation influences their enthusiasm but not their level of worry, with a general expectation of more negative than positive outcomes from machines taking over human jobs.

Americans show strong support for limiting robots and computers to jobs considered dangerous or unhealthy, with 85% in favor, and this sentiment is consistent across party lines [6, 9]. Specifically, 85% of Democrats/lean Democrat and 86% of Republicans/lean Republican support the idea of machines primarily doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs [image3].

![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of Democrats/lean Dem (blue) and Republicans/lean Rep (red) who support various policies:

1. "Machines do dangerous or unhealthy jobs only": 85% (Democrat/lean Dem), 86% (Republican/lean Rep).
2. "All citizens guaranteed a basic income": 77% (Democrat/lean Dem), 38% (Republican/lean Rep).
3. "National service program for displaced workers": 66% (Democrat/lean Dem), 46% (Republican/lean Rep).
4. "People can pay extra to interact with a human": 63% (Democrat/lean Dem), 61% (Republican/lean Rep).](image3)

However, opinions diverge significantly on other policies. Democrats are more supportive than Republicans of a universal basic income (77% vs. 38%) and a national service program (66% vs. 46%) in the event of widespread job losses due to automation [2, 5, 9].

![The image is a bar chart illustrating public opinion on two issues related to automation and job displacement. Each section shows the percentage of people who agree with each statement, broken down by overall U.S. adults, education levels, and political affiliation. 

1. The first set of bars addresses whether the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers, even if it means raising taxes, versus whether individuals have an obligation to care for their own well-being if machines have taken many jobs:
   - 50% of U.S. adults believe the government has an obligation, while 49% think individuals should care for themselves.
   - By education level:
     - 45% (College grad+), 51% (Some college), and 53% (High school or less) agree with the government obligation.
     - Correspondingly, 54%, 48%, and 45% believe in the individual's obligation.
   - By political affiliation:
     - 30% of Republicans/lean Republican and 65% of Democrats/lean Democrat believe in the government obligation.
     - Conversely, 68% of Republicans/lean Republican and 34% of Democrats/lean Democrat believe in the individual's responsibility.

2. The second set of bars discusses whether there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, even if they are better and cheaper than humans, versus whether businesses are justified in replacing human workers if machines can do the job better and at a lower cost:
   - 58% of U.S. adults think there should be limits, while 41% believe businesses are justified.
   - By education level:
     - 41% (College grad+), 59% (Some college), and 70% (High school or less) agree on imposing limits.
     - Conversely, 59%, 40%, and 27% agree with business justification.
   - By political affiliation:
     - 54% of Republicans/lean Republican and 60% of Democrats/lean Democrat agree on limits.
     - Conversely, 44% of Republicans/lean Republican and 39% of Democrats/lean Democrat agree with business justification.](image4)

Despite the partisan differences on income and service programs, there is more alignment on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, although it show a little difference [4]. 60% of Democrat and 54% of Republican feel that there should generally be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with robots or computers [9].

Public opinion shows strong bipartisan support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs, while Democrats are more supportive of government intervention policies like universal basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans.

Public opinion on the government's role in caring for workers displaced by automation is sharply divided along political lines. A significant majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (65%) believe the government has an obligation to take care of these workers, even if it means higher taxes [3]. Conversely, a nearly identical percentage of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (68%) believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3]. Overall, the public is evenly split on this issue, with 50% favoring government responsibility and 49% favoring individual responsibility [5].
![Opinions by political affiliation and education.](image4)
However, views on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines show more agreement across party lines. A slight majority of Republicans (54%) believe there should be limits on automation, which is not far off from the 60% of Democrats who hold that view [7]. Educational attainment also plays a significant role in opinions on automation limits. A large majority (70%) of those with a high school diploma or less support limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate, compared to only 41% of college graduates [10]. Democrats are also far more supportive of a guaranteed basic income (77% vs 38% of republicans) [2].
![Support levels for policies by Democrats and Republicans.](image2)
The most popular policy idea among all Americans is limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with a majority of 85% favoring the policy [8].

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly impacts views on the government's obligation to assist displaced workers, while education level strongly influences opinions on limiting automation, with bipartisan support existing for some limits.

Political affiliation significantly shapes Americans' views on policies related to workforce automation. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are considerably more supportive of a universal basic income (77% favor) compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (38% favor) [1]. A similar trend is observed with a national service program, favored by 66% of Democrats versus 46% of Republicans [1].
![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of Democrats/lean Dem (blue) and Republicans/lean Rep (red) who support various policies.](image4)
However, both groups show similar levels of support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs [10]. Additionally, views on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines are comparable between Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) [6, 10].
![The image is a bar chart illustrating public opinion on two issues related to automation and job displacement. Each section shows the percentage of people who agree with each statement, broken down by overall U.S. adults, education levels, and political affiliation.](image3)
There's a sharp divide regarding the government's obligation to support workers displaced by automation [4]. A majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government should take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes, while a nearly identical share of Republicans (68%) believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [4].

In summary, political affiliation significantly impacts views on government intervention and support for workers affected by automation, with Democrats generally favoring more government involvement and Republicans prioritizing individual responsibility.

Workforce automation and technology's impact elicit varied responses across different demographics. A minority of Americans have already experienced direct consequences, such as job loss due to automation [2]. Specifically, 2% of Americans report losing a job because their positions were replaced by machines or computer programs, and 5% have had their pay or hours reduced for the same reason [2].

Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 24, are among the groups most likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation [2].
![U.S. adults in different age groups who either lost a job or had their pay or hours reduced.](image3)
This age group reported a 6% job loss and an 11% reduction in pay or hours, compared to the overall U.S. adult population, where 2% lost jobs and 5% had reduced pay or hours [image3].

Educational attainment also significantly influences perceptions of technology in the workplace [3, 5]. Generally, workers with higher levels of education tend to view workplace technologies more positively [3].
![Education Level vs. perceived benefits of education in workplace.](image4)
College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53%), compared to those with a high school diploma or less, who reported 38% and 32%, respectively [image4, 10].

Various technologies, such as word processing software and smartphones, are generally perceived positively.
![Perceived impact of various technologies](image1)
For instance, 70% of workers reported a positive impact from word processing or spreadsheet software, and 67% reported a positive impact from smartphones [image1]. However, a substantial share also views these technologies as damaging or neutral to their career prospects [1]. Those who have not attended college are much less likely to view today's workforce technologies in such a positive light [7].

In summary, attitudes toward workforce automation and the impact of technology are more positive among younger individuals and those with higher educational attainment, while also showing that some people lost their job or had their pay or hours reduced.

Workers' views on how technology impacts their careers differ significantly based on their educational backgrounds [1]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more engaging and increased their career opportunities, compared to those with a high school diploma or less [1, 5]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of those with a high school education or less share this view [1, 9]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has boosted their career advancement opportunities, compared to 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [1, 9].

![Educational attainment strongly influences perceptions of technology's impact on job interest and career advancement.](image4)

A substantial portion of workers see technological advancements in a positive light, but others view them as detrimental or neutral to their careers [4]. These benefits are more often experienced by workers with higher levels of education [4, 6]. The survey results also showed that workforce automation has resulted in job losses or reduced wages for a minority of workers, many of whom view technology negatively [4].

![Job loss and reduced pay or hours among different age groups in the U.S. due to automation.](image1)

The impact of technology on workers can manifest in various forms, such as job loss or reduced hours and pay [4]. For instance, younger workers (aged 18-24) are more likely to report negative effects, with 6% having lost jobs and 11% experiencing reduced pay or hours, compared to 1% and 2% for workers over 65 [4].

In general, workers who have not attended college are much less likely to view today’s workforce technologies in such a positive light [6].

The perceptions of the impact of workforce automation and technology is that it varies significantly across different demographics, with higher-educated workers reporting more positive impacts than those with less education.

Workers' perceptions of how technology impacts their jobs, in terms of interest and advancement opportunities, vary significantly based on their education levels and the specific technologies involved [1], [3].

![Workers with higher levels of education more likely to say tech has increased opportunities, made their jobs more interesting](image1)

Workers with higher levels of education, particularly those with college degrees, are more likely to report that technology has had a positive impact on their careers [3], [5]. They often find that technology makes their work more interesting and increases their opportunities for career advancement [6], [7]. This is supported by the finding that a substantial share of workers believe technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have positively impacted their careers [9].

In contrast, workers with a high school diploma or less are less likely to view workforce technologies positively [3], [8]. Only 38% of these workers indicate that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and just 32% feel it has increased their career advancement opportunities [7].

![Workers express more positive than negative views on the overall impact of technology on their careers](image2)

Overall, while many workers view technology as beneficial, a significant portion, especially those without higher education, do not share the same optimism [1], [2], [4]. Technology, in general, is seen by 53% of workers as making their work more interesting and by 46% as increasing career advancement opportunities, but these views are less prevalent among workers with lower educational attainment [2], [10].

In summary, higher education levels correlate with a more positive perception of technology's impact on job interest and advancement, with specific technologies like software and smartphones being widely viewed as beneficial, particularly by college-educated workers.

The emotional reactions to social media content vary significantly across different age groups [10]. Younger users, aged 18-29, report frequently feeling amused (54%) more often than older users [1, 5]. However, younger users are also more likely to experience negative emotions, such as loneliness (15%) and depression (17%), compared to older adults [5, 9].
![Emotional Reactions to Social Media Content by Age Group](image2)
Older adults, aged 65 and older, show a more balanced response, with similar percentages reporting feeling amused (30%) and angry (24%) [5]. Across all age groups, the most frequently experienced emotion is amusement, with 44% of users reporting they often feel this way [7].
![Frequency of Emotions Experienced on Social Media](image3)
In addition to amusement, a significant portion of users also frequently encounter content that makes them feel angry (25%) [3, 6]. Many users also encounter dramatic or exaggerated posts and people making accusations without having all the facts [2].
![Frequency of Encountering Certain Types of Posts on Social Media](image1)

In conclusion, while amusement is the most common emotion experienced by all users, younger users report a wider range of emotions, including higher rates of loneliness and depression, compared to older users who report a more balanced mix of amusement and anger.

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media, with some notable variations. Younger adults, aged 18 to 29, are more likely to report feeling amused frequently (54%) compared to older adults aged 65 and older (30%) [7]. This is visually represented in a dot plot showing the emotional responses across age groups, where the 18-29 age group (green dots) shows higher percentages for amusement [7].

The chart depicts how different age groups react emotionally, particularly highlighting that younger people (18-29) tend to report stronger emotions across all categories compared to older age groups.](image1)
However, younger adults are also more likely to frequently encounter content that makes them feel lonely (15%) compared to older adults (4%) [1].

In terms of content exposure, a majority of social media users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [5].

   - Sometimes: 45%
