In conclusion, younger adults on social media report higher levels of amusement but also loneliness, while users of all ages frequently encounter dramatic and accusatory content.

Different age groups exhibit varied emotional responses to social media content. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults aged 30-49 (7%) and those 50 and older (4%) [7]. Conversely, older adults are less likely to be amused by content, with similar shares of those 65 and older reporting feeling amused (30%) and angry (24%) [7]. A visual representation of these emotional responses across age groups can be seen in the following chart:

![Emotional responses of different age groups to humorous or amusing content.](image2)

Regarding gender differences, men are more likely than women to encounter mean or bullying behavior (29% vs. 19%) [2, 4]. Men are also more likely to perceive people as trying to be deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10, 4].

![Comparison of Men's and Women's experience of online behavior.](image4)

The most common types of content users frequently encounter are posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [4]. These findings are further detail :

![Frequency of different types of posts encountered by users.](image5)

In summary, younger adults are more prone to loneliness on social media, while older adults show less variation in feeling amused versus angry. Men are more likely to encounter negative behaviors and deception, and the most common content types involve drama and unfounded accusations.

Social media users experience a range of emotions and encounter various types of content, with some differences noted across age groups and genders.

A significant portion of users, 44%, frequently feel amused by content they see on social media, while another 44% sometimes feel amused [2].
![Emotional responses on social media.](image2)
Younger users (18-29) report feeling amused more frequently (54%) compared to older users (65+) (30%) [4].
![Emotional responses on social media by different age group.](image4)
Content that is overly dramatic or exaggerated is frequently seen by 58% of users, and 59% frequently encounter people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts [9].

![Frequency of encountering different type of posts on social media.](image5)
In terms of behavior, 24% of users report seeing people being mean or bullying more often, while 21% see people being kind or supportive more often [8]. Men are more likely (29%) than women (19%) to report seeing mean or bullying behavior more often [10].
![Comparison of perceptions of online behavior between men and women.](image3)
Users' comfort levels with how social media platforms use their data vary depending on the context [1]. A majority find it acceptable for platforms to recommend local events (75% somewhat or very acceptable) [2], but not for delivering political campaign ads (38% somewhat or very acceptable, 62% not very or not at all acceptable) [2].
![Acceptability of different online recommendations.](image1)

In conclusion, different age groups and genders experience a mix of emotions and behaviors on social media, with younger users reporting stronger emotional responses and men more frequently encountering negative behaviors, while the most common types of posts are overly dramatic or involve unsubstantiated accusations.

Social media users encounter a mix of behaviors, and there are notable differences between how men and women perceive these interactions [9]. For instance, men are more likely than women to report seeing people being mean or bullying (29% vs. 19%) [10].
![Men are more likely than women to perceive online interactions as mean or bullying.](image1)
This chart also shows that 24% of men, compared to 13% of women, more often see people trying to be deceptive [5]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to report seeing kind or supportive behavior (24% vs. 17%) [8, 10]. However, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [5].

In terms of the content they encounter, a significant majority of users frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) [3, 7].
![Many users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts.](image4)
The frequency is similar for those seeing posts with accusations or arguments without all the facts (59%) [3].

In conclusion, men are more likely to perceive online interactions as involving bullying and deception, while women are more likely to see supportive behavior, amidst a general backdrop where many users frequently encounter dramatic or exaggerated posts.

Social media users' comfort with platforms using their personal data is highly dependent on the context [1, 2].

Perceptions of online behavior vary significantly between men and women. Men are more likely to report seeing mean or bullying behavior (29% of men vs. 19% of women) and deceptive behavior (24% of men vs. 13% of women) [4, 10].
![Perceptions of online behaviors differ between men and women.](image2)
Conversely, women are more likely to report seeing kind or supportive behavior (24% of women vs. 17% of men) [4]. However, the majority of both men (52%) and women (56%) report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [4].

These differences in perception suggest that social media platforms could tailor their content moderation and recommendations based on gender.
![Acceptability ratings for different online recommendations.](image5)
For instance, a majority (75%) finds it acceptable for platforms to use data to recommend local events [3].
![Acceptability ratings for online recommendations across different age groups.](image1)
Acceptance varies for other uses, such as recommending friends or showing ads for products [9].

In conclusion, men are more likely to perceive negative behaviors, such as bullying and deception, on social media, while women are more likely to notice supportive and kind interactions, which informs how platforms might tailor content and recommendations.

User comfort with social media platforms' use of personal data is highly dependent on the context and purpose for which the data is used [7, 8]. A significant majority of social media users, around 75%, are comfortable with their data being used to recommend local events [1, 4]. Acceptance rates for event recommendations are relatively high across all age groups, with 67% of users aged 65+, 72% of those aged 50-64, 78% of those aged 18-29, and 80% of those aged 30-49 finding it acceptable [9].
![Chart comparing how different age groups feel about certain types of recommendations and advertisements they receive.](image1)
However, comfort levels decrease when data is used for other purposes [5]. For instance, acceptance drops significantly when the data is used to deliver political messages [1]. Only 31% of users aged 65+, 35% of those aged 50-64, 38% of those aged 18-29, and 40% of those aged 30-49 find it acceptable for social media platforms to use their data to show them political campaign messages [image1]. A substantial majority find this unacceptable, with 31% saying it is "not acceptable at all" [5].

There are notable differences among age groups regarding the use of data for recommending connections [6]. While about two-thirds of users younger than 50 are comfortable with platforms using their data to suggest new friends, fewer than half of users aged 65 and older share this view [6, 10]. Specifically, 66% of users aged 18-49 find it acceptable, compared to only 36% of users aged 65 and older [10].
![This image is a bar chart showing the acceptability of different online recommendations.](image2)
For advertising products or services, around half (52%) of users find it acceptable, but a similar share (47%) finds it unacceptable [5].

In summary, different age groups vary significantly in their acceptance of social media platforms using their data, with older users generally being less accepting, particularly for recommendations of people they might know, while most users are comfortable with data being used for local event recommendations but wary of its use for political messaging.

The public generally views the fairness and effectiveness of automated decision-making systems similarly, with one notable exception: the personal finance score [4].

A majority, 54%, believe that personal finance scores are effective in helping businesses find new customers, while only 32% find them fair to consumers [8]. This is a 22% difference, it is the most significant among the scenarios presented [8].
![Perceived Effectiveness and Fairness of Automated Systems](image3)

In contrast, other systems like automated video analysis of job interviews, automated resume screening, and automated scoring for parole have smaller differences between perceived effectiveness and fairness [3].

The automated criminal risk score is viewed as fair by 50% of Americans, whereas only 32% believe the personal finance score is fair to consumers [1]. There's concern that these tools might violate privacy, not capture nuanced situations, or place people in unfair situations [6]. The personal finance score algorithm is overwhelmingly deemed unacceptable by 68% of Americans [9].
![Reasons for Not Accepting Automated Personal Finance Scores](image2)
The responses further highlight that the public views the fairness of the decision across four different systems differently.
![Perceptions of Fairness in Automated Decision-Making](image4)
Additionally, opinions vary among demographic groups, particularly regarding race and ethnicity. White individuals are more concerned about consumer finance scores compared to Black and Hispanic individuals, while Black individuals express more concern about parole scoring algorithms [3]. Generally, older age groups are more skeptical about programs making unbiased decisions, and there is a trend that they feel computer program will always reflect some level of human bias [6].
![Perceptions of Bias in Automated Systems Across Age Groups](image1)

These differences imply that while people acknowledge the potential effectiveness of automated systems, particularly in finance, they harbor significant concerns about fairness, privacy, and potential biases, especially regarding the group of people being evaluated [6, 7].

Public perception of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials is notably low compared to previous administrations [1, 7]. This sentiment is reflected across different political affiliations, though with significant partisan divides. A majority of the public (58%) reports trusting what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents [9].

Specifically, a striking 94% of Democrats and Democratic leaners express less trust in Trump's statements compared to those of previous presidents [2]. This is visually represented in a bar chart showing the stark contrast between Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats concerning their trust in Trump relative to previous presidents.
![Chart comparing responses from different political affiliations about trust.](image4)

Conversely, a majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (58%) say they trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents [6]. Only 39% rate the ethical standards as good or excellent [4].
![The image is a chart showing approval ratings of U.S. presidents at different times in their terms.](image1)

These ratings represent record lows when compared to previous administrations, dating back to the 1980s [1]. The partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that 76% of Republicans and Republican leaners rate the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners rate them as not good or poor [10].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are significantly lower compared to previous presidents, with a deep partisan divide where Democrats overwhelmingly distrust Trump more, while a majority of Republicans trust him more.

A majority of the public (58%) says they trust what Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said while in office [10]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Democrats and Democratic leaners, with 94% expressing less trust in Trump's statements compared to previous presidents [5].
![Public trust in Trump compared to previous presidents.](image3)
In contrast, 58% of Republicans and Republican leaners say they trust what Trump says more than previous presidents [8].

There's also a growing expectation for Trump to release his tax returns. A majority (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to publicly release his tax returns, including 91% of Democrats and 32% of Republicans [3].
![Opinions on Trump's responsibility to release tax returns over time.](image1)
The data indicates a significant partisan divide in the perception of Trump's trustworthiness and responsibilities compared to previous presidents.

Public opinion on Donald Trump's presidency is deeply divided along partisan lines, covering trust, ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success.

Regarding ethical standards, a significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (76%) believe that the ethical standards of top administration officials are excellent or good [10]. In stark contrast, 90% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals rate these standards as not good or poor [10]. Views of Trump administration officials are lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations [7].
![Opinions on whether something made things better, had not much effect, or made things worse, categorized by political affiliation.](image4)

The economic impact of Trump's policies shows a similar partisan divide. Nearly eight-in-ten Republicans (79%) believe his policies have improved economic conditions [9], as shown in the significant "Better" rating in image4. Conversely, 46% of Democrats believe his policies have made things worse [9]. Overall, 40% of the public thinks Trump's policies have had a positive impact on the economy [4].

![Comparison of perceptions of presidential success among party affiliates at different points in their presidencies.](image5)

As for long-term success, 65% of Republicans predict Trump will be a successful president [3], a view mirrored by similar percentages for Bush in 2003 [6]. However, only 29% think he will be a successful president [5]. This is lower than for Obama and George W. Bush at comparable points in their administrations [5]. The data for multiple presidents is also shown in image5.
![Approval ratings of U.S. presidents at different times in their terms.](image1)
The approval of Trump in January 2019 is 39, which is lower than most presidents at comparable points in their administrations [image1].

In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized, with Republicans largely positive about his ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term prospects, while Democrats hold predominantly negative views. These perceptions generally align with or are more negative than those of previous presidents at similar stages.

The perceptions of Trump's presidency differ significantly from those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton, particularly among party affiliates, with noticeable shifts in public opinion trends.

In January 2019, 65% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believed Trump would be a successful president [1], while 80% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believed he would be unsuccessful [5]. This contrasts sharply with earlier presidencies. For instance, in December 2003, 69% of Republicans thought Bush would be successful [10], closely mirroring the support for Trump among Republicans.

![Perceptions of presidential success among party affiliates, comparing Trump, Obama, Bush, and Clinton.](image1)

However, a key difference is the level of uncertainty. In January 2019, only 25% of Republicans and 16% of Democrats said it was "too early to tell" about Trump's success [2]. These figures were much lower than at comparable points for previous presidents. For example, 47% of the public said it was too early to tell for Obama in his third year, 38% for Bush, and 43% for Clinton [4]. The data reveals a more polarized and definitive view of Trump's presidency, with fewer people undecided compared to his predecessors.

Overall, the comparison highlights a greater partisan divide and a quicker consolidation of opinions regarding Trump's presidency compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton.

The trends indicate that public is more decisive about Trump's success compared to his three predecessors.

Public perception of Donald Trump's potential success as president is sharply divided along party lines. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, 65%, believe that Trump will be a successful president in the long run [6]. This is visually demonstrated by a bar chart. ![Party affiliates' perceptions of presidential success.](image3) In stark contrast, a large majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals, 80%, believe that Trump will be an unsuccessful president [3].

These differing views on Trump's potential success correlate with levels of confidence in Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian involvement in the 2016 election. Overall, 55% of the public expresses confidence in Mueller's investigation being fair [8], with confidence levels remaining relatively stable over the past year [5]. This stability is visually presented in a time-series bar chart showing consistent levels of "Somewhat" and "Very" confident responses from December 2017 to January 2019. ![Confidence levels in Mueller's investigation over time.](image5)

However, confidence in the Mueller investigation is also deeply partisan [4]. Among Democrats and Democratic leaners, 72% are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Mueller's investigation [7]. Conversely, a larger share of Republicans and Republican leaners, 58%, express a lack of confidence in Mueller [7]. This partisan divide is further reflected in opinions on Trump's handling of matters related to the investigation, with 92% of Democrats expressing a lack of confidence in Trump, while 75% of Republicans express confidence [9]. The levels of confidence among all respondents and sorted by party are shown. ![Respondents level of confidence.](image2)

In summary, perceptions of Trump's potential success are highly polarized, with Republicans largely optimistic and Democrats overwhelmingly pessimistic, and these perceptions are closely tied to differing levels of confidence in Mueller's investigation and Trump's handling of it.

Public views on local job availability are currently the most positive they have been in decades [9]. Currently, a majority of both Republicans (71%) and Democrats (53%) believe there are plenty of jobs available locally [6]. This positive sentiment aligns with broader, more favorable views of the economy [10]. However, there's a notable partisan gap in these perceptions [7, 2]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view job availability positively [2].

Although majorities in both parties see jobs as available, the perception differs when it comes to "good jobs" [4]. There remains a gap in views regarding the availability of jobs versus "good jobs," [8] suggesting that while people acknowledge the presence of jobs, they may be less optimistic about the quality of those jobs. Views of local job opportunities in both parties are among the most positive in the last two decades. [5].

In summary, Perceptions of job availability are positive across both parties but with a significant partisan gap, with Republicans more optimistic than Democrats.

Public perception of job availability varies significantly between political affiliations, with Republicans generally holding a more optimistic view than Democrats [10]. Currently, 71% of Republicans believe there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [10].  This partisan gap is visually represented in a line graph showing the trends in political affiliation from 2001 to 2019.

Public opinion on Wall Street's impact is sharply divided along partisan lines. Republicans are more likely to believe that Wall Street helps the U.S. economy more than it hurts it [1, 8]. Specifically, 55% of Republicans and Republican leaners hold this view, compared to 31% who think it hurts the economy more [3].
![Chart showing Wall Street's impact on the economy by political affiliation.](image3)
Democrats, on the other hand, are more divided. 46% of Democrats and Democratic leaners believe Wall Street does more to hurt the economy, while 41% say it does more to help [3, 7].

These differing views on Wall Street's impact correlate with broader trends in national satisfaction levels, which also vary significantly by political affiliation.
![The graph shows the percentages of people who are Dissatisfied and Satisfied with national conditions from 1990 to 2019.](image1)
Overall satisfaction with the state of the nation is low, with 70% of Americans expressing dissatisfaction [3]. However, this dissatisfaction is particularly pronounced among Democrats [2], while Republicans show a more mixed response [9].

In conclusion, Republicans generally view Wall Street positively and are more likely to be satisfied with national conditions, whereas Democrats are more critical of Wall Street and express higher levels of dissatisfaction with the nation's state.

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has significantly decreased from 1990 to 2019. In 1990, 41% of Americans were satisfied with the way things were going in the country, but by 2019, this figure had dropped to 26% [2]. Conversely, dissatisfaction rose from 54% in 1990 to 70% in 2019.  ![The percentage of people who are "Dissatisfied" and "Satisfied" with the way things are going in the country from 1990 to 2019](image2)

Political affiliations have also fluctuated over this period. The trends show shifts in party alignment during different presidencies, with Democratic support generally exceeding Republican support during Obama's terms. However, under Trump, the gap between the parties narrowed [5].
![Political affiliation trends over time from 1990 to 2019](image5)

These shifts in public satisfaction and political affiliation correlate with divided views on Wall Street's impact on the economy [7, 8]. Republicans are more likely to believe that Wall Street helps the economy (55%) compared to Democrats (41%) [7]. Democrats are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy and 41% saying it helps [3].
![Chart showing the percentage of people who think that Wall Street impacts the American economy in different ways](image4)

In conclusion, public satisfaction decreased significantly between 1990 and 2019, accompanied by fluctuating political affiliations, and these trends reflect partisan divisions in views on Wall Street's economic impact.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts varies significantly between Republicans and Democrats. A substantial majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (88%) express confidence (64% "Very," 24% "Somewhat") in Trump's ability in this area [4]. In sharp contrast, only a small fraction of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (12%) share this confidence (2% "Very," 10% "Somewhat")  ![A bar chart comparing confidence levels in political abilities between Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats on various issues.](image3).

This partisan divide mirrors the confidence levels observed in other tasks. For instance, in negotiating favorable trade agreements, 89% of Republicans express confidence, compared to only 19% of Democrats [1]. Similarly, regarding making good decisions about economic policy, 89% of Republicans are confident, versus just 17% of Democrats [4].

When it comes to managing the executive branch effectively, 52% of Republicans report being "Very" confident and 31% as "Somewhat" confident, compared to a mere 2% of Democrats who are "Very" confident and 6% who are "Somewhat" confident. The confidence that the general public has in Trump to manage a variety of governmental task is more mixed. !['Very', 'Somewhat', 'Not too', 'Not at all' confident about task management ability](image1).

In summary, there is a stark contrast between Republicans' and Democrats' confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts, reflecting a broader pattern of partisan division across various tasks.

A majority of Americans express limited confidence in President Trump's ability to keep his business interests separate from his presidential decisions. Only about 28% are very confident, and another 13% are somewhat confident [4]. A significant portion, 41%, are not at all confident [4]. This sentiment is sharply divided along political lines.

Republicans, particularly conservatives, display much higher confidence. A majority of Republicans, 55%, report being very confident, with another 23% somewhat confident [10]. Conservative Republicans are notably more likely (66%) to express high confidence compared to moderate and liberal Republicans (39%) [10].
![Confidence levels in Trump's ability to keep business interests separate](image3)

Conversely, Democrats overwhelmingly lack confidence. Nearly 70% are not at all confident, and an additional 20% are not too confident [2]. This skepticism is even more pronounced among liberal Democrats, with 83% expressing no confidence at all [2].

Regarding the release of tax returns, most Americans (64%) believe Trump has a responsibility to release them [8].
![Responsibility of releasing tax return.](image4)
However, this view is not uniformly held. Most Republicans (64%) do not believe Trump has this responsibility, while only 32% think he does [3]. The data consistently highlights a partisan divide in perceptions of Trump's ethical obligations and actions.

Public trust in Trump's statements is also lower compared to previous presidents, with 58% indicating they trust him less [5].
![Public trust in Trump's statements compared to predecessors.](image5)

In conclusion, confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests and presidential decisions varies greatly by political affiliation, with Republicans being far more confident than Democrats, mirroring contrasting views on his responsibility to release tax returns.

Partisan divides significantly affect perceptions of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions. Republicans and Democrats have divergent opinions about nearly all aspects of the coronavirus outbreak [1].

A significant majority of Democrats (87%) believe the U.S. response to the coronavirus has been less effective compared to other wealthy countries, whereas a smaller percentage of Republicans (34%) share this view [1]. A plurality of Republicans (42%) believe the U.S. response has been about as effective as other wealthy nations, while only 8% of Democrats agree with this [1].
![Opinions on U.S. COVID-19 response compared to other wealthy nations, categorized by political affiliation.](image1)

There's also a clear difference in confidence levels towards various institutions and leaders. For instance, a majority of Republicans (73%) express confidence in Donald Trump, compared to a mere 6% of Democrats [2].
![Confidence levels in various institutions and leaders, differentiated by political affiliation.](image2)

The ratings for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have decreased among both Democrats (from 84 to 72) and Republicans (from 74 to 53) between March and August [5], The overall total decreased from 79 to 63 [5]. Democrats are more inclined to give positive ratings to their state and local government officials for their response to the outbreak than Republicans [9].

In conclusion, partisan divides significantly impact perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness, with Democrats generally viewing the U.S. response more negatively and showing greater trust in public health officials and their local and state governments compared to Republicans.

Partisan differences significantly impact perceptions of the COVID-19 response. There's a widening gap between Republicans and Democrats in their views of public health officials and Donald Trump.

Democrats generally maintain a consistent, positive view of public health officials, with about 72% saying these officials have done an excellent or good job responding to the coronavirus, which is largely unchanged since March (74%) [10]. Republicans, however, show a steep decline in positive assessments, dropping 31 percentage points from 84% in March to 53% [10]. This is further illustrated by a line graph showing the approval ratings over time.
![Public health officials such as those at the CDC: The rating for Democrats/Lean Democrats decreased from 84 to 72.The rating for Republicans/Lean Republicans dropped from 74 to 53.The overall total decreased from 79 to 63.](image3)

Regarding Donald Trump, the vast majority of Democrats (82%) rate his response as "poor," a significant increase from 56% in March [9]. The approval of Donald Trump from Democrats/Lean Democrats decreased from 18 to 6 [image3]. Republicans' views of Trump's response have also decreased, but not as drastically.
![Donald Trump:The rating for Republicans/Lean Republicans decreased from 83 to 73.The overall total dropped from 48 to 37. The rating from Democrats/Lean Democrats decreased from 18 to 6.](image3)
There are much wider partisan differences in views of public health officials [5].
![Hospitals and medical centers in your area: Democrats/Lean Democrats: 87%, Republicans/Lean Republicans: 90%,Total: 88%; Public health officials such as those at the CDC: Democrats/Lean Democrats: 72%, Republicans/Lean Republicans: 53%, Total: 63%.](image5)

In conclusion, partisan differences show a growing divide in perceptions of the COVID-19 response, with Democrats largely maintaining confidence in public health officials, while Republicans' confidence has significantly decreased, and a vast majority of Democrats disapproving of Trump's response.

From March to August, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have declined, with significant partisan differences.

The overall approval rating for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, decreased from 79% to 63% [1]. This decline is primarily attributed to a sharp drop in approval among Republicans. In March, 84% of Republicans rated public health officials positively, which fell to 53% by August [9]. Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with 74% approving in March and 72% in August [9].
![Approval ratings for Public Health Officials from March to August](image4)
Similarly, Donald Trump's overall approval rating for his handling of the coronavirus outbreak decreased from 48% to 37% [image4]. The partisan divide is stark in Trump's case as well. Among Republicans, the approval rating decreased from 83% to 73%. Among Democrats, it dropped from 18% to 6% [image4].
![Approval ratings for Donald Trump from March to August.](image4)
These changes highlight a growing partisan divide in the perception of the response to the coronavirus outbreak. The percentage of those with party affiliation of Democrat/Lean Democrat who say public health officials are doing well is 72% [7]. The percentage of those with party affiliation of Republican/Lean Republican who say Donald Trump is doing well is 73% [image3].

In summary, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have decreased from March to August, with a significant drop in approval among Republicans for both, while Democratic approval remained relatively low for Trump and stable for public health officials.

Americans hold differing views on the COVID-19 responses of state governments versus that of Donald Trump. Evaluations of state government officials' response to the coronavirus outbreak have declined since March, with 56% rating it as excellent or good [10]. However, a sizable majority of U.S. adults (69%) express greater concern that state governments have been lifting restrictions on public activity too quickly [2].

![Opinions on the speed of lifting coronavirus outbreak restrictions, with a majority believing restrictions are being lifted too quickly.](image5)

In contrast, the public's assessment of Donald Trump's response is more negative. Nearly half of Americans (48%) rate Trump's response to the outbreak as "poor," [4, 6] which is a significant increase in negative ratings since March [4].

![Public opinion ratings for various groups and individuals, including Donald Trump, regarding their performance during the pandemic.](image1)

The data indicates a clear difference, with a larger proportion of Americans criticizing Trump's response negatively compared to their assessment of state governments, although there is still considerable concern about the speed at which states have lifted restrictions.

In conclusion, American perceptions show a more negative view of Trump's handling of the pandemic compared to state government responses, with a considerable portion concerned about the rapid lifting of restrictions by state governments.

Americans' views on the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic vary significantly between elected officials and public health officials. While a majority still view public health officials positively, their approval ratings have declined since March [2]. Specifically, 63% of Americans believe public health officials, such as those at the CDC, are doing an excellent or good job, a decrease from 79% in March [2].

In contrast, the approval ratings for elected officials are lower. Local elected officials are viewed as doing an excellent or good job by 60% of respondents, while state elected officials are viewed positively by 56% [5]. The lowest ratings are for Donald Trump, with only 37% of people rating his response as excellent or good, and nearly half rating it as "poor" [4, 6]. The performance from various groups and individuals show that local hospitals and medical centers got the highest score, NET 88%, while Donald Trump got the lowest, 37%.
![Public opinion ratings for various groups and individuals regarding their response to the outbreak.](image4)

Several factors are perceived as contributing to the continued COVID-19 outbreak. A significant majority (75%) believe that a major reason is that not enough people are adhering to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [8].
![Reasons for the spread of COVID-19, with different levels of perceived importance.](image1)
Additionally, 58% think that lifting restrictions too quickly in some places is a major reason for the continued outbreak [8]. Other factors include an inadequate response from the federal government (53%) and not enough timely testing (49%) [10].

In summary, Americans generally have a more favorable view of public health officials than elected officials in handling the COVID-19 response, and the continued outbreak is largely attributed to insufficient adherence to guidelines and premature lifting of restrictions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed stark differences in perception based on political affiliation, particularly regarding government responsibility and reasons for the outbreak's continuation.

A significant majority (75%) of Americans, cite insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason for the continued spread of COVID-19 [1]. This view is particularly strong among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (89%), though a majority of Republicans and GOP leaners (57%) also agree [3, 5].
![The chart categorizes each reason as a major, minor, or not a reason for the spread, using different shades of color.](image1)

There are also considerable differences between Republicans and Democrats of responsibilities. Democrats are more likely to believe that the federal government should be primarily responsible (64%), while Republicans tend to favor state and local governments (68%) [9].
![The chart categorizes each reason as a major, minor, or not a reason for the spread, using different shades of color.](image5)
These differences indicate that 48% trust the federal government, and 51% trust state and local governments [4].
![There are no responses shown for those who didn't answer.](image4)

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic, with Democrats favoring federal government responsibility and Republicans preferring state and local government control. The most commonly cited reason for the continuation of the outbreak is insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing.

Americans are divided along political lines regarding the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly concerning government response and social distancing [1]. A significant majority of Democrats (82%) believe that an inadequate federal government response is a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to only 21% of Republicans [5, 9].
![Disparities in opinions on COVID-19 related issues based on political affiliation.](image5)
The inadequate response from the federal government has been cited as the reason in the continuation of the COVID-19 [4]. This partisan divide is also evident in opinions about social distancing and the lifting of restrictions.

A large majority of Americans (75%) cite insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason [6]. Democrats are more likely to agree with this compared to Republicans (89% vs 57%) [7].
![Major reasons for the spread of an issue.](image4)
There's also disagreement over whether restrictions were lifted too quickly. While 82% of Democrats believe this is a major reason, only 31% of Republicans agree [5, 10]. The differing views are also highlighted about the reason in the continuation of the covid-19, Democrats are more likely than Republicans that most factors are the major reasons [5].

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of the COVID-19 outbreak's continuation, with Democrats largely blaming inadequate federal response and premature lifting of restrictions, while Republicans are less likely to attribute the continuation to these factors.

A majority of Americans (53%) believe that an inadequate federal government response is a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak [5]. This perception differs significantly between political affiliations.

Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate [3]. Specifically, 82% of Democrats see this as a major reason the outbreak has continued, compared to only 21% of Republicans [3].

Lack of timely testing (49%) and unclear instructions on prevention (40%) are also factors [5].

In summary, perceptions of the federal government's response to the COVID-19 outbreak differ greatly between Democrats and Republicans, and major reasons cited for the outbreak's continuation include insufficient social distancing, premature lifting of restrictions, and inadequate federal response.

There are significant differences between Republican and Democratic views on why the COVID-19 outbreak continued and whether enough measures were taken. Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to several factors [7].

A significant majority of Democrats (82%) believe an inadequate federal government response is a major reason the outbreak has continued, compared to only 21% of Republicans [7]. The perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions vary significantly across political affiliations.

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily due to increased testing [7]. Democrats overwhelmingly (80%) attribute the rise to more infections [7].

A significant majority of adults (76%) strongly or somewhat favor requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote [9]. However, there are notable differences in these preferences across racial and ethnic groups.

Among Democrats, while a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor this requirement, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) express the same support [2]. The provided image also compares values associated with these racial groups, highlighting support levels.

Black adults also show lower levels of support of policies such as requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification [8].

Republicans overwhelmingly support the policy of requiring government-issued photo ID (93%) [3].

In conclusion, while a majority of U.S. adults favor requiring photo ID to vote, support is higher among Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats compared to White Democrats, and it is overwhelmingly high among Republicans.

Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for various voting policies, including photo identification requirements and early or absentee voting, with variations observed both within and across party lines.

Within the Democratic Party, there is a notable difference in support for requiring government-issued photo identification [2]. A majority of White Democrats (54%) favor this policy [2]. ![Larger shares of Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats support requiring government-issued photo identification to vote.](image1) However, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support the same measure [2]. This indicates a higher level of support for photo ID requirements among non-White Democrats.

In terms of early or absentee voting, White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than are Democrats of other races and ethnicities [10]. Black adults are more likely than White, Hispanic, and Asian adults to favor 'no excuse' early, absentee voting [1].

Among Republicans, racial and ethnic differences also play a role, although the data is more limited due to the smaller sample sizes of Black and Asian Republicans [7].

Overall, partisanship remains a dominant factor in attitudes toward voting policies [8].

In conclusion, racial and ethnic differences influence support for voting policies, with variations observed within and across party lines, particularly in support for photo ID requirements and early/absentee voting.

Support for requiring government-issued photo identification to vote is widespread, but it varies significantly across racial and political lines [10]. A large majority of adults (76%) either strongly or somewhat favor this requirement [10].

However, there are notable differences in the intensity of this support between Republicans and Democrats [9]. Republicans are considerably more likely to strongly favor photo identification requirements, with 81% expressing strong support, compared to just 30% of Democrats [9].

Within the Democratic Party, racial differences are also apparent [6]. While a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring photo ID, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support the same policy [6].

In terms of voting accessibility, Black Americans uniquely prefer more expansive policies. For example, Black Adults are distinctively favour allowing people convicted of felonies to vote after their sentences at 85%, compare to other races and ethnicities at 70% [7]. Black adults also exhibit the lowest levels of support for more restrictive policies, such as removing people from registration lists for inactivity and requiring photo ID [5].

In contrast to policies, White Democrats is more supportive for allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than are Democrats of other races and ethnicities [2]. Among Republicans, White adults are less supportive than Hispanic adults of policies aimed at easing voting [3].

In summary, while a majority supports photo ID requirements for voting, the intensity of this support varies by political affiliation, and opinions on voting accessibility policies differ significantly across racial and ethnic groups within the same party.

Americans generally favor the option to vote early or absentee, with slightly more than 60% supporting this view [6]. However, there are significant differences across political and demographic lines.

Partisanship plays a crucial role, with only 38% of Republicans supporting no-excuse early and absentee voting, compared to 84% of Democrats [3, 7]. This partisan divide is further illustrated by the fact that a proposal by House Democrats to require independent redistricting commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans is met with approval by 49% of all US adults and 59% of Democrats, but only 38% of Republicans support.
![Approval of redistricting commissions is higher among Democrats than Republicans.](image2)

Ideological divides within the Republican party also exist, with moderate and liberal Republicans being more evenly split on the issue, while 70% of conservative Republicans believe voters should be required to provide documented reasons for voting absentee or early [9].
![Ideological differences within the Republican party regarding absentee and early voting.](image1)

Experience with early or absentee voting also influences opinions. Republicans who voted absentee or by mail in 2020 are more likely to favor no-excuse absentee or early voting (52%) compared to those who voted in person on Election Day (22%) [10].
![Republicans who voted absentee are more likely to support no-excuse absentee voting.](image4)

In summary, support for no-excuse early and absentee voting is high among Democrats and varies within the Republican party based on ideology and prior voting experience, while independent redistricting commissions are met with approval by Democrats and less so by Republicans.

Data indicates varied perspectives on voting methods and redistricting based on political affiliation. A significant portion of U.S. adults, nearly half, approve of a proposal by House Democrats for redistricting commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans, rather than state legislatures controlling the process [3]. The overall approval rating for this proposal is 49%, with only 13% disapproving and 38% unsure [5].

![49% of people Approve of a proposal that would require all states to put together committees with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans who would be responsible for determining the state’s congressional maps](image5)

Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more likely to disapprove (19%) compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals (8%) [8], [5]. There's also a higher level of uncertainty among Republicans (42%) compared to Democrats (32%) regarding these non-legislative commissions [8], [5].

Regarding early and absentee voting, there is a clear partisan divide, particularly among Republicans. Republicans who voted absentee or by mail are more supportive of "no excuse" absentee or early voting (52%) compared to those who voted in person early (35%) or on Election Day (22%) [7].

![The chart shows the breakdown of how different groups of voters cast their ballots in the 2020 election.](image3)

Among Democrats, the support for "no excuse" absentee or early voting is consistently high, regardless of how they voted [7]. Ideological divides are more prominent among Republicans, with conservative Republicans (70%) more likely than moderates and liberals (49%) to say voters should be required to provide documented reasons for voting absentee or early [9].

![The bar chart shows the percentage of people who have different requirements about Voting Early or Absentee.](image4)

Different political affiliations have distinct views on voting methods and redistricting, with Republicans showing more internal division and uncertainty compared to Democrats.

Public opinion on early or absentee voting and automatic voter registration has shifted between 2018 and 2021, particularly among Republicans.

Regarding "no excuse" early or absentee voting, the percentage of Republicans supporting this option has significantly decreased from 57% in October 2018 to 38% in April 2021 [3, 5]. Conversely, Republicans who believe a documented reason should be required for early or absentee voting rose from 42% to 62% [2]. Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with 83-84% consistently supporting no-excuse early or absentee voting [2, 5].
![Views on early or absentee voting from 2018 to 2021](image2)

As for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, Democrat support slightly increased from 78% to 82% between 2018 and 2021 [1, 5]. On the other hand, Republican support for automatic voter registration decreased from 49% to 38% [7, 5].
![Changes of view in automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote](image3)

In summary, from 2018 to 2021, Republican support for "no excuse" early or absentee voting decreased, while their support for automatic voter registration also declined; Democratic support for both policies remained high and relatively stable.

Partisan views on making Election Day a national holiday and requiring photo ID to vote have evolved distinctly between 2018 and 2021.

Regarding making Election Day a national holiday, the support among Republicans has remained constant at 59% [2]. Democrat support has increased from 71% to 78% [2].
![The image shows survey data about opinions on voting reforms over two time periods: October 2018 and April 2021. The opinions are divided into three groups: total, Republican/Lean Republican (Rep/Lean Rep), and Democrat/Lean Democrat.](image2)
On the issue of requiring photo ID to vote, Republican support has slightly increased from 91% to 93% [2, 6]. In contrast, Democrat support decreased from 63% to 61% [2].
![The image shows a survey of people's opinions on various voting-related issues, divided by political affiliation (Total, Republican/Lean Republican, Democrat/Lean Democrat).](image5)
However, majorities in both partisan groups still favor this policy [4]. Democrats are more likely to strongly favor proposals aimed at making it easier to vote, Republicans are more likely to strongly support requiring voters to show photo ID [9].

In summary, from 2018 to 2021, Republican support for making Election Day a national holiday remained stable, while Democratic support increased; Republican support for requiring photo ID to vote slightly increased, whereas Democratic support slightly decreased.

Latino voters' party affiliations have remained relatively stable from 2019 to 2022, with a consistent preference for the Democratic Party. The Democratic Party's support among Latino registered voters was 62% in 2019, peaked at 66% in 2021, and slightly decreased to 64% in 2022. The Republican Party's support started at 34% in 2019, decreased to 31% in 2021, and then slightly increased to 33% in 2022 [2].
![Party Affiliation Over Time](image2)

The economy has consistently been the most important issue for Latino voters, with 80% saying it was very important in both March and August 2022 [10]. However, the importance of abortion as a voting issue has significantly increased, rising from 42% in March to 57% in August 2022 [8].
![Issue Importance Over Time](image3)

Preferences vary among demographic groups. For example, 53% of Latino registered voters would vote for the Democratic candidate, while 28% would vote for the Republican candidate [9].
![Voter Preferences by Demographic Group](image4)

The majority (73%) of Latino registered voters believed that Donald Trump should not remain a national political figure.
![Opinions on Donald Trump's Political Role](image1)

There are perceived differences among Hispanics based on political affiliation.
![Perceived Differences Among Hispanics](image5)

In summary, Latino voters have maintained a steady preference for the Democratic Party from 2019 to 2022, with the economy remaining the top issue and abortion rising significantly in importance; preferences vary by demographic factors such as political and religious affiliation.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans hold significantly different views on both Trump's future political role and the perception of racial discrimination.

Regarding Trump's future, a large majority of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) do not want him to remain a national political figure [7].
![Hispanic registered voters have different views on if Trump should stay in politics.](image4)
In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners want Trump to remain a national political figure [7].

On the issue of racial discrimination, there's a clear divide. Nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and leaners (73%) believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a bigger problem [1].
![This image shows how different Latino groups, categorized by political affiliation and the importance of their Hispanic identity, perceive racial discrimination.](image5)
A majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (62%), on the other hand, say it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it does not exist [1].

In summary, Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's continued political involvement and are concerned about the denial of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Republicans largely favor Trump's continued influence and are more concerned about false accusations of racism.

Latino registered voters hold diverse views on Donald Trump's political future, and these views often intersect with their concerns about racial discrimination and gun rights. A significant majority of Hispanic registered voters (73%) believe that Trump should not remain a national political figure [8]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Latino Democrats, with 94% expressing this view [8]. ![This bar chart shows the percentage of each group that thinks Trump should not remain in politics and those that think he should, including those who think he should run for president himself and those who think he should support another candidate who shares his views.](image4)

However, opinions differ significantly along party lines. Among Hispanic Republicans, 63% want Trump to remain a national political figure, with 41% of them supporting his potential run for president in 2024 [6].

These partisan divisions among Latinos are also reflected in their views on racial discrimination. Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to say that people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem [9]. ![The image is a bar graph comparing perceptions of racial discrimination among different groups of Latinos.](image5)

Regarding gun rights, a substantial majority of Hispanics (73%) prioritize controlling gun ownership over protecting the right to own guns [7]. ![This bar chart illustrates the opinions of different groups within the U.S. on two opposing perspectives: "Protect the right of Americans to own guns" and "Control gun ownership."](image3) This view is more pronounced among Hispanic Democrats (85%) compared to Hispanic Republicans (45%) [7]. These differences of opinion are consistent with broader national trends, indicating the significant role of party affiliation in shaping these perspectives [3].

In summary, Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are sharply divided along party lines, mirroring their differing concerns about racial discrimination and gun control, with Democrats generally opposing Trump's continued influence and prioritizing social issues, while Republicans are more supportive.

Latino voters exhibit significant differences based on political affiliation regarding both Donald Trump's future political role and the perception of racial discrimination.

A substantial majority of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners (63%) believe that Trump should continue as a national political figure [6], with nearly half (47%) expressing that he should run for president in 2024 [7]. Conversely, a decisive majority of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [6].
![Opinions on whether Trump should remain a national political figure, broken down by demographics and political affiliation.](image5)

Regarding racial discrimination, the views are similarly divided. About six-in-ten Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (62%) believe that a bigger problem is people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist [10].
![Perceptions of racial discrimination among different groups of Latinos.](image2)
In stark contrast, nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (73%) say that a bigger problem is people not seeing racial discrimination where it does exist [10].

In summary, Hispanic Republicans largely favor Trump's continued political involvement and are more concerned about perceived false accusations of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's continued involvement and are more concerned about the failure to recognize genuine racial discrimination.

Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism show notable differences based on political affiliation and age [9].

For capitalism, a majority of Hispanics have a positive impression (54%) [4, 7]. This is further differentiated by political lines: 68% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners view capitalism positively, compared to 50% of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners [1].
![The image is a bar chart showing the net attitudes of different groups toward a particular topic. The groups include ](image3)

When it comes to socialism, 53% of Hispanics have a negative impression, while 41% have a positive one [2]. Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split, with 50% viewing socialism positively and 48% negatively [8].
![The image is a stacked bar chart showing the perceptions of certain groups towards being Hispanic or Hispanic identity. The responses are categorized into four groups: ](image5)
In contrast, a significant majority of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (72%) hold a negative view of socialism.

Age also plays a crucial role in these perceptions. Among Latinos aged 18 to 29, views on socialism are almost evenly divided, with 46% reporting a positive impression [5, 6]. However, majorities of Latinos aged 50 to 64 (60%) and 65 and older (61%) view socialism negatively [5].

In summary, Hispanic perceptions of capitalism are generally positive, with higher favorability among Republicans. Views on socialism are more divided, with Democrats being split, Republicans mostly negative, and older age groups more likely to have negative impressions.

Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly depending on their political affiliation.

Regarding socialism, Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split, with 50% viewing socialism positively and 48% negatively [4]. In stark contrast, a significant majority of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (72%) hold a negative perception of socialism. Only 24% have a positive perception [3].
![Perceptions of socialism among different groups, including Hispanic Democrats and Republicans](image3)

When it comes to capitalism, about two-thirds of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (68%) have a positive view [6]. Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners show a less positive but still favorable view, with 50% having a positive impression of capitalism [6].
![Attitudes of Hispanics, categorized by political affiliation, towards capitalism](image1)

In summary, Hispanic Republicans have a more positive view of capitalism and a more negative view of socialism compared to Hispanic Democrats.

The data reveals significant differences in how various demographic groups within the Latino community perceive political parties' efforts to earn their votes.

Among all Latinos, a notable portion (36%) identify with the Democratic Party, while a smaller share (19%) align with the Republican Party [1].
![Bar chart showing percentages of Latinos identifying with Democrats or Republicans, broken down by demographic categories.](image1)
There are clear variations across demographic categories. For instance, 44% of foreign-born Latinos identify as Democrats, compared to 29% of U.S.-born Latinos [1]. Similarly, 48% of Spanish-dominant Latinos identify as Democrats, while only 23% of English-dominant Latinos do the same[1].

When asked about the statement "Democrats work hard to earn Latinos' votes," many Latinos, including immigrants (44%), Spanish-dominant Latinos (48%), Catholics (42%), and evangelical Protestants (42%), agree that it describes their views very or extremely well [9]. The same is true for those ages 50 to 64 (45%) and 65 or older (46%)[9].
Among Latinos who say the statement "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos’ votes" describes their views well [8].

Fewer Latinos believe that "Republicans work hard to earn Latinos' votes" [6]. Only about one-in-five Latinos (19%) agree with this statement [3].
![Chart showing how different groups of Latinos perceive certain efforts, split into \"Not too/Not at all well,\" \"Somewhat well,\" and \"Very/Extremely well.\"](image4)
Even among Latino Republicans, only 40% say the statement describes their views well, compared to 13% of Latino Democrats [3].
There is a great deal of difference between what the parties stand for, according to 54% of Hispanic Democrats and 57% of Hispanic Republicans [1].
![Chart showing varied perceptions on differences between groups, categorized by political affiliation and registration status.](image2)
However, smaller shares of independent Hispanics who lean Democratic (35%) and lean Republican (39%) see such a stark difference [1].

In conclusion, perceptions of political parties' efforts to earn Latino votes vary significantly across demographic groups, with higher approval for Democratic efforts among immigrants, Spanish-dominant Latinos, and older age groups, while Republicans receive lower approval ratings overall, even among their own constituents.

Latino registered voters tend to favor the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a significant margin [2]. Party affiliation among Latinos has remained relatively stable in recent years [2, 10].

![Party affiliation among Latino registered voters, 2019-2022.](image2)

However, there are notable differences in how partisans view each party's engagement with Latino voters. A majority of Hispanic Republicans (56%) believe the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latinos' votes [1], while a smaller percentage of Hispanic Democrats (35%) say the same about the Republican Party [1].

![The survey shows the percentage of Dem/Lean Dem and Rep/Lean Rep who shared the described views.](image5)

Similarly, 36% of Latino Republicans think the Democratic Party genuinely cares about Latinos, compared to 21% of Latino Democrats who believe the Republican Party cares about Latinos [8]. In broader terms, many Hispanics perceive differences between the two major parties [3, 5]. However, a substantial portion sees either a fair amount of difference (36%) or hardly any difference at all (16%) between the parties [5].
![Perception of differences in the Democratic and Republican parties among Hispanics.](image3)

In conclusion, perceptions differ significantly, with Hispanic Republicans more likely to view the Democratic Party's efforts positively than Hispanic Democrats view the Republican Party's efforts, and these perceptions align with the relatively stable trend of Latino voters favoring the Democratic Party.

The perceptions of party differences and support among Hispanics have remained relatively stable in recent years, with some variations based on political affiliation [10]. Latino registered voters significantly favor the Democratic Party over the Republican Party, by a nearly two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [8]. This preference has shown little change over the past few years, as depicted in the trend data.
![Latino party affiliation little changed in recent years](image2)

About half of Hispanics do not see a great deal of difference between the Democratic and Republican parties [6]. Specifically, 45% of Hispanics see a great deal of difference, 36% see a fair amount of difference, and 16% see hardly any difference at all [6]. These perceptions are similar among both Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (47%) and Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (48%), who say there is a great deal of difference between the parties [6].
![The image is a chart displaying survey results about the perceived differences among Hispanics based on political affiliation.](image5)

Majorities of Latino adults express positive views of the Democratic Party [9]. 71% say the Democratic Party works hard for Latinos’ votes, 63% say it “really cares about Latinos,” and 60% say the Democratic Party represents the interests of people like them [9]. In comparison, a smaller portion of Latinos say the same about the Republican Party.
![The image is a series of bar graphs comparing perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties regarding their relationship with Latino voters.](image4)

Detailed breakdown by party affiliation shows that 78% of Democrats or those leaning Democratic believe the Democratic Party really cares about Latinos, compared to 36% of Republicans or those leaning Republican [10]. Conversely, 68% of Republicans or those leaning Republican believe the Republican Party really cares about Latinos, while only 21% of Democrats or those leaning Democratic think the same [10].
![Latino perceptions by party affiliation](image1)

In summary, a majority of Hispanics prefer the Democratic Party, with perceptions of party differences being relatively consistent across party lines, though there are notable variations in how each party is viewed by its supporters and opponents.

The views of Latino voters on the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties have shown some nuances. About half of Hispanics do not perceive a significant difference between the two major parties [1]. Specifically, 45% of Hispanics see a "great deal of difference," while 36% see a "fair amount of difference," and 16% see "hardly any difference at all" [1].

![Perceived Differences among Hispanics Based on Political Affiliation](image1)

When broken down by party affiliation, the perceptions are nearly identical. Among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, 47% see a great deal of difference, compared to 48% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners [1].

Latino registered voters predominantly identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party, with a nearly two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%) [6]. This party identification has remained relatively stable over the past few years [2, 6].

![Party Affiliation Trend of Latino Voters](image2)

However, a substantial portion of Latino voters have soft ties to political parties.

The data shows that a significant percentage of Latino voters do not perceive major differences between the two main parties, but they do mainly favor the democratic party.

In recent years, the views of Latino voters regarding differences between the Democratic and Republican parties show that about half do not see a great deal of difference, yet party affiliation has remained relatively stable, with a strong preference for the Democratic Party [2,6].

Americans generally view STEM jobs favorably, especially concerning compensation [3, 8]. A significant majority (71%) believe that STEM jobs offer higher pay compared to other industries [3, 4].
![Perceptions of STEM jobs and pay](image4)
However, perceptions of STEM job characteristics vary between men and women, particularly in areas beyond salary. While both genders value flexibility in balancing work and family life about equally [9], there are notable differences in other job aspects.
![Job characteristics comparison between men and women](image1)
Men in STEM are more likely than women to prioritize high pay and opportunities for promotion [9]. Specifically, 59% of men versus 48% of women value high pay, and 57% of men versus 46% of women value promotion opportunities [image1]. Conversely, women in STEM are more inclined than men to value jobs that focus on helping others (59% of women compared to 31% of men) [9, image1].

In summary, while STEM jobs are widely perceived to offer higher pay, men in STEM prioritize high pay and promotion opportunities more than women, whereas women in STEM place a higher value on jobs that help others.

Men and women in STEM fields share a common emphasis on work-life balance, as indicated by the fact that 71% of men and 76% of women value "having flexibility to balance work/family" [9]. This is further illustrated in a visual comparison:
![Having flexibility to balance work/family is valued highly by both men and women in STEM.](image4).

However, significant differences emerge in other job characteristic preferences. Men in STEM tend to prioritize financial and career advancement, with 59% valuing "having a high-paying job" and 57% valuing "opportunities for promotion," compared to 48% and 46% of women, respectively [7].

Conversely, women in STEM place a higher value on societal impact and helping others. A significant 59% of women, compared to 31% of men, prioritize "having a job focused on helping others" [7, 1, 9]. Similarly, 60% of women versus 51% of men value "making a meaningful contribution to society". The visual representation of this data highlights these disparities:
![Women in STEM value helping others more than men do.](image4)

These differing priorities relate to the challenges women face entering the STEM workforce. Many women feel that early education does not encourage girls enough in STEM subjects [4, 5]. Moreover, about half of women in STEM jobs (48%) believe that gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major obstacle, compared to only 29% of men [10]. Discrimination is listed as major reason:
![Discrimination is the biggest reason why there are not more women in STEM.](image3)

The underrepresentation of women in certain STEM fields over time, particularly in computer science, which decreased from 32% in 1990 to 25% in 2016 is a matter of concern:
![The number of women is decreasing in computer science.](image2).

In summary, while both genders value work-life balance, men in STEM prioritize pay and promotion more, while women emphasize helping others and making a societal contribution; these differences are linked to perceived barriers like lack of early encouragement and workplace discrimination that hinder women's entry into STEM.

Americans perceive a range of factors contributing to the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM fields [10]. A significant 39% of Americans believe that a lack of encouragement for girls to pursue STEM from an early age is a major reason for their underrepresentation [6].
![The image is a bar chart that illustrates the major reasons why more women, blacks, and Hispanics are not in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) jobs. ](image1)
For blacks and Hispanics, 41% cite the same lack of early encouragement as a major factor [6]. Another primary concern for blacks and Hispanics is limited access to quality education, which 42% of Americans consider a major reason for their underrepresentation in STEM [9].

Discrimination also plays a perceived role, though views differ significantly among groups. About half of women (48%) in STEM jobs see gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions as a major reason there are not more women in STEM, compared to 29% of men in STEM jobs [3]. Among those in STEM, 72% of blacks say that a major reason why blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented is due to facing discrimination in recruiting, hiring and promotions, while only around a quarter of whites (27%) and Asians (28%) say the same [5].

In summary, the main reasons for underrepresentation differ: for women, discrimination and work/family balance are often cited, whereas for blacks and Hispanics, lack of access to quality education and less encouragement from a young age are seen as primary factors.

STEM-employed individuals generally have higher levels of education compared to non-STEM-employed individuals. Specifically, a larger percentage of STEM workers hold bachelor's degrees (36%) and postgraduate degrees (29%) [7], in contrast to non-STEM workers, where the percentages are 21% and 12%, respectively [5].
![Educational attainment among employed adults, ages 25 and older, by STEM and non-STEM occupation](image2)

The predominant employment sectors for STEM workers show variations depending on the specific field. A majority of STEM workers, similar to all employed adults, work for private, for-profit employers (66%) [8]. However, there are differences within STEM fields. For instance, engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are more likely to work for a private employer [8].
![Employment sectors across job categories](image4)

In contrast, fewer healthcare practitioners and technicians work in the private, for-profit sector (58%), with a significant portion working for not-for-profit employers (23%) [8]. The distribution of STEM workers in government and self-employment is generally lower compared to their non-STEM counterparts [10].

In summary, STEM-employed individuals are more highly educated than non-STEM employees, with a majority working in the private, for-profit sector, though this varies by specific STEM field.

STEM workers generally have higher levels of education compared to non-STEM workers [6]. Approximately 65% of STEM workers have at least a bachelor's degree, compared to 32% of non-STEM workers [6]. Additionally, about 29% of STEM workers hold a master's, doctorate, or professional degree, significantly exceeding the 12% of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees [6]. This difference in educational attainment is visually represented in a chart.
![Educational attainment of STEM vs. non-STEM workers](image2)

The employment sector trends show specific patterns within STEM fields from 1990 to 2016. For instance, in computer-related jobs, there was a decline in a certain characteristic from 32 in 1990 to 25 in 2016, whereas, in engineering, there was a modest increase from 12 to 14 over the same period.
![Trends in Computer and Engineering sectors over time](image1)

Most STEM workers, about 66%, are employed in the private, for-profit sector, a figure substantively identical to that of all employed adults [4]. However, this distribution varies within specific STEM fields; for example, 82% of engineers and architects, and 77% of computer workers, are employed in the private sector, while only 58% of healthcare practitioners and technicians work in the same sector [4]. Many of the healthcare practitioners work for not-for-profit employer [4].
![Employment distribution across various job categories.](image3)

In summary, STEM workers are about twice as likely to have higher educational qualifications than non-STEM workers, with significant variations in employment sectors over time.

Experiences of discrimination in STEM jobs differ significantly among racial groups. Black STEM employees report the highest incidence of discrimination, with 62% saying they have experienced discrimination at work due to their race or ethnicity [3, 5, 7]. This is notably higher than the rates reported by Asians (44%), Hispanics (42%), and Whites (13%) in STEM jobs [5, 7].
![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing four categories with corresponding percentages: - White: 13% - Black: 62% - Hispanic: 42% - Asian: 44% ](image5)

Regarding gender-based discrimination, 50% of women in STEM jobs report having experienced discrimination due to their gender [6]. This rate is significantly higher than that of men in STEM occupations (19%) [6]. The types of gender discrimination experienced by women in STEM include earning less than men doing the same job (29%), being treated as if they were not competent (29%), experiencing repeated, small slights at work (20%), and receiving less support from senior leaders (18%) [6]. The survey indicates that such challenges are even more, especially in male-dominated environments.
![The image is a bar chart comparing the experiences of women and men in STEM jobs regarding workplace issues, segmented by gender composition within the workplace ("More women/even gender mix" and "More men").](image1)

In conclusion, while gender discrimination is a significant issue for women in STEM, racial discrimination is particularly pronounced for Black STEM employees, who report the highest rates of discrimination among all racial groups surveyed.

Women in STEM jobs who work in majority-male workplaces face significantly greater challenges related to gender discrimination and inequities compared to those in more gender-balanced settings. A substantial 78% of women in majority-male workplaces report experiencing gender discrimination, compared to 44% of women in workplaces with more women or an even gender mix [6, 8]. This disparity is further highlighted by the fact that nearly half (48%) of women in male-dominated STEM environments believe their gender has hindered their career success, versus only 14% in more gender-balanced settings [8, 4].
![Experiences of women in STEM jobs differ based on gender composition in the workplace.](image4)
Moreover, women in majority-male workplaces are more likely to feel the need to constantly prove themselves to be respected by their coworkers [3, 7]. Specifically, 79% of women in male-dominated workplaces feel the need to prove themselves, compared to 52% in workplaces with a more even gender mix [4].

![Gender discrimination in STEM, with a breakdown of experiences among women.](image1)

Common forms of discrimination experienced by women in STEM include earning less than a man doing the same job, being treated as if they were not competent [9], and gender has been an impediment to success on the job [4].
The attention given to gender diversity also differs significantly, with 43% of women in majority-male workplaces feeling that their workplace pays too little attention to this issue, compared to only 15% in more balanced settings [4].

In conclusion, women in STEM jobs in male-dominated environments experience higher rates of gender discrimination, feel a greater need to prove themselves, and perceive that their gender is more of a hindrance to success compared to those in more gender-balanced workplaces.

Several factors influence Hispanic self-identification in the U.S., and these factors evolve across generations. Racial and ethnic identity in the U.S. has been based on self-reports since the 1960s: You are what you say you are [5].

One key aspect is the diminishing connection to Hispanic ancestry as generations progress. By the third generation, 77% self-identify as Hispanic, and by the fourth or higher generation, only half do so [1].
