The SnapNTell model's architecture incorporates both entity detection (ED) and retrieval augmentation (RA) to enhance its performance.
![Our SnapNTell model architecture takes an image-question pair as input. It begins with retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image.](image9)
The inclusion of entity detection (ED) significantly contributes to the model's overall effectiveness [2]. Specifically, the model's performance markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature. This highlights the necessity of the entity detection step in the model's performance [2].

Retrieval augmentation (RA) also plays a crucial role. The model leverages retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image [9]. Retrieval augmentation enhances performance across various entity types, and the performance improvement for torso-to-tail entities far exceeds that of head entities [1]. It is effective in addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities [1]. The efficiency of retrieval augmentation in producing responses enriched with entity-centric information illustrates its substantial impact on the task [4].

In summary, the inclusion of entity detection significantly improves the model's overall effectiveness, while retrieval augmentation enhances performance across various entity types and addresses hallucination issues, especially for long-tailed entities.

The SnapNTell model demonstrates superior performance compared to existing baseline models across all assessed metrics [5]. This improvement is largely due to the integration of retrieval augmentation, which enhances responses with entity-centric information [5].
![Our SnapNTell model architecture takes an image-question pair as input. It begins with retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image. This information, along with the question, feeds into the word embedding layer. Text embeddings merge with image-projected embeddings before entering the LLM, culminating in a knowledge- able answer as the output.](image1)
The model's architecture, as depicted in, begins with retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image [2].
The evaluation of model is in the metrics of Recognition Accuracy, Response Accuracy and Pairwise Comparison [1]. In pairwise comparisons, the model shows a smaller difference when measured against manually annotated ground-truth samples, outperforming the baselines and underscoring its robustness [7].
Furthermore, an ablation study confirmed the significant contribution of entity detection to the model's overall effectiveness [10].

In conclusion, the SnapNTell model outperforms other models due to its retrieval augmentation and entity detection components, demonstrating superior accuracy and robustness in evaluations.

The impact of entity detection (ED) on the performance of SnapNTell is significant, as demonstrated by an ablation study that compared performance with and without the ED component [4]. The results of this study clearly indicate that the approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature [4]. This highlights the significant contribution and necessity of the entity detection step in the model's overall effectiveness [4].

In summary, the inclusion of Entity Detection significantly improves SnapNTell's performance.

SnapNTell is a novel task and dataset introduced to address challenges that Vision Language Models (VLLMs) face with long-tail entity queries, which often result in inaccurate or hallucinated responses [5].

The evaluation of the SnapNTell task involves several NLP metrics, including BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE, and BLEURT [9]. Additionally, accuracy and hallucination rate metrics are used, employing GPT-4 to measure the proportion of correct versus incorrect or partially incorrect answers [9]. A human evaluation process is also conducted, involving a panel of five judges assessing responses based on specific instructions [8]. The ROUGE and BLEURT scores were found to be more indicative in distinguishing differences among various models, aligning closely with human judgment [4].

The proposed method for the SnapNTell task, a retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM, demonstrated superior performance over existing baseline models across all assessed metrics [7]. This highlights the efficiency of retrieval augmentation in producing responses enriched with entity-centric information [7]. Results from a comparative analysis on various VQA datasets demonstrate performance disparities with lower scores than its scores, which indicates SnapNTell dataset is particularly effective in evaluating the capabilities of different models to recognize entities and produce responses centered around these entities [10]. Although the proposed approach often neared human-level performance, it did not consistently outperform human annotations, indicating opportunities for future advancements [2].

In conclusion, SnapNTell outperforms existing methods in terms of evaluation metrics, and while nearing human-level performance, it does not consistently surpass human annotations.

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance in document classification and competitive results in citation prediction compared to other baseline models. In document classification, SPECTER achieves an 86.4 F1 score on the MeSH dataset and 82.0 on the MAG dataset, which shows a notable improvement over other models [5].
![Performance metrics for different models or configurations.](image1)
Specifically, it outperforms the best baseline by approximately 2.3 and 1.5 points, respectively [5]. In citation prediction tasks, SPECTER shows strong results, particularly in co-citation metrics where it achieves the best nDCG of 94.8, surpassing even SGC by 2.3 points [5].
![Comparison of model performance across various tasks.](image3)
Visually, the topic clustering reveals significant differences between SPECTER and SciBERT.
![Topic clustering visualization comparing SPECTER and SciBERT models.](image2)
SPECTER's embeddings show more compact and well-separated clusters, indicating a better encoding of topical information [6]. Quantitatively, SPECTER achieves higher homogeneity (0.41) and completeness (0.72) scores compared to SciBERT's scores (0.19 and 0.63, respectively), confirming the improved separation of topics in the embedding space [6].

In summary, SPECTER outperforms other models in document classification, is highly competitive in citation prediction, and shows visually and quantitatively superior topic clustering compared to SciBERT.

The SPECTER model generally outperforms other models across a range of tasks, including document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation [1, 6, 7]. For instance, in document classification, SPECTER achieves an 86.4 F1 score on the MeSH dataset, outperforming the best baseline by 2.3 points [6].
![Comparison of models across tasks](image4)
In user activity prediction, SPECTER shows significant improvements over baselines in co-view and co-read tasks [6]. SPECTER's embeddings are better at encoding topical information.
![SPECTER vs. SciBERT Clustering](image1)
It also excels in citation and co-citation prediction tasks, even surpassing models like Citeomatic and SGC, which have access to the citation graph during training and testing [6].

Including additional metadata like venue and author information has mixed effects on SPECTER's performance. Adding venue information slightly decreases performance except on document classification.
![Ablation study results](image5)
Adding author information, surprisingly, hurts performance, possibly due to sparsity of author names or suboptimal tokenization [3, 4]. The fact that SPECTER does not require inputs like authors or venues makes it applicable in situations where this metadata is not available [4].
![SPECTER model overview](image2)
Fine-tuning SciBERT on specific tasks is generally inferior to using the fixed representations from SPECTER [10].
![Performance Comparison of SPECTER and Fine-tuned SciBERT](image3)

In summary, the SPECTER model demonstrates superior performance compared to other models across various tasks, and the inclusion of venue information can help on document classification, while author information generally decreases performance.

Different data augmentation techniques have varying impacts on the performance of BERT models, particularly evident in the QQP dataset experiments. One approach involves constructing synthetic training sets with different positive-negative ratios from the original QQP dataset (which has 37% positive and 63% negative examples) [2].

When using the Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) objective, augmenting with positive examples (`+positive`) outperforms the original dataset, while augmenting with negative examples (`+negative`) underperforms. This aligns with expectations since `+positive` creates a more balanced dataset, and `+negative` creates a more imbalanced one [6].
![Performance Variations of BERT Models Under Different Conditions](image5)
This effect is measured using F1 scores, and creating a balanced dataset, as in the `+positive` case, improves performance, whereas creating a more imbalanced dataset, like `+negative`, leads to lower performance [6].
Another measurement is show that DSC achieves the highest F1 score across all datasets. Specially, for + positive , DSC achieves minor improvements (+0.05 F1) over DL. [3].

However, removing negative examples (`-negative`), despite creating a balanced dataset, results in inferior performance due to the reduced number of training data [6]. The table illustrates these variations, showing that BERT+DSC consistently achieves the most significant improvements in F1 scores compared to other variations like BERT+FL and BERT+DL across different configurations.

These findings are measured not only on paraphrase identification tasks like QQP but also in accuracy-oriented tasks such as sentiment classification on the SST datasets [1].
![Accuracy Results for Sentiment Analysis with BERT Variants](image1)
In sentiment analysis, using Dice Loss (DL) or DSC Loss functions does not improve accuracy compared to using Cross-Entropy (CE). For example, on the SST-5 dataset, BERT with CE achieves an accuracy of 55.57, while DL and DSC perform slightly worse (54.63 and 55.19, respectively) [1].

In summary, data augmentation techniques impact BERT model performance differently based on the balance and size of the augmented data, with balanced datasets generally improving performance, while imbalanced or reduced datasets may degrade it, as measured by F1 scores in paraphrase identification and accuracy in sentiment analysis.

The performance differences among various BERT model configurations can be observed across different augmentation techniques and datasets.

In summary, BERT+DSC generally shows the highest performance across different datasets and augmentation techniques, particularly demonstrating significant improvements in imbalanced dataset scenarios.

COMET-RANK generally outperforms BLEU in evaluating translation quality across various language pairs. This is evidenced by higher correlation scores in multiple comparisons. For instance, when evaluating language pairs with English as the source [10], COMET models, including COMET-RANK, consistently outperform other metrics like BLEU, often by significant margins.

![The table presents the results of a translation performance metric called COMET-RANK for various language pairs. The first row lists the language pairs, using ISO language codes; for example, "en-cs" refers to English to Czech, and "cs-en" refers to Czech to English. The metrics are evaluated in two scenarios: using only reference translations (COMET-RANK (ref. only)) and using the COMET-RANK metric more generally. The values in this table represent scores that likely indicate the quality of translation, with higher values suggesting better performance. ](image1)

Specifically, the inclusion of the source in the COMET-RANK model improves the overall correlation with human judgments [7]. Also, COMET based metrics also had the better performance than the BLEU based methods when English is the target language [2].
![The image contains five line graphs, each representing the performance of different machine translation (MT) evaluation metrics over various top MT systems translated into English from different languages. The graphs are titled based on language pairs: de-en (German to English), fi-en (Finnish to English), lt-en (Lithuanian to English), ru-en (Russian to English), and zh-en (Chinese to English).](image2)

Classic metrics like BLEU are characterized as n-gram matching metrics, which means they estimate translation quality by counting the number and fraction of n-grams that appear in both the candidate translation and human references [1]. This approach often fails to capture semantic similarity beyond the lexical level [1].

![The table presents evaluation metrics for machine translation systems across various language pairs. The languages indicated are German-English (de-en), Finnish-English (fi-en), Gujarati-English (gu-en), Kazakh-English (kk-en), Lithuanian-English (lt-en), Russian-English (ru-en), and Chinese-English (zh-en).](image3)

COMET, on the other hand, is a neural framework for training MT evaluation models that adapts and optimizes to different types of human judgments [3].
Even in language pairs that do not include English, COMET models demonstrate strong and consistent performance [4].

![The table presents the performance of various metrics for evaluating machine translation quality across three language pairs: German-Czech (de-cs), German-French (de-fr), and French-German (fr-de). The metrics assessed are BLEU, chrF, YiSi-1, BERTScore (using both default and XLM-R base settings), and three variations of COMET: COMET-HTER, COMET-MQM, and COMET-RANK. Each metric shows its corresponding score for each language pair, with higher scores typically indicating better translation quality. Notably, COMET-RANK achieves the highest scores in its respective language pairs when compared to other metrics.](image4)

The observed trend is that COMET metrics generally maintain a higher level of performance, whereas, BLEU scores are noticeably lower across all system sets, with the performance decreasing as fewer top models are assessed.
![The image consists of two line graphs that display the performance of various metrics across different sets of machine translation (MT) systems. The caption indicates that the metrics' performances are evaluated over all systems, as well as the top 10, 8, 6, and 4 systems.](image5)

In summary, COMET-RANK consistently outperforms BLEU in evaluating translation quality, showing higher correlation scores and better adaptability across different language pairs, particularly excelling in scenarios involving more complex semantic analysis.

DS-DST and DS-Picklist are two models designed for dialog state tracking (DST), and they show improvements over other methods, including those based on BERT [1, 5, 7, 9].

In terms of joint accuracy, DS-Picklist outperforms DS-DST. On the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, DS-Picklist achieves a joint accuracy of 53.30%, while DS-DST achieves 51.21% [1].
![The table presents a comparison of different models based on their joint accuracy. The joint accuracy values are likely related to the effectiveness of dialogue state tracking or some other natural language processing task.](image1)

DS-Picklist shows a similar level of joint accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.0 dataset.

The first column lists the models and their corresponding authors, while the other two columns show the accuracy results for each model on the two datasets.](image4)

As for slot accuracy, the performance of the models varies depending on the slot type [3, 4]. DS-DST and DS-Picklist significantly improve over the DS-Span baseline for slots where values have different expressions and cannot be extracted from the dialog context [3].
![This table displays accuracy percentages for various slots across three different models: DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist. The slots are related to a dialogue state tracking (DST) task, typically used in natural language understanding systems for applications such as booking systems or intelligent assistants. The slots include categories like hotel-type, attraction-name, restaurant-name, among others.](image5)
These slots include `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [3, 4]. For these types of slots, treating them as categorical slots is better, as the predicted values can be found in candidate-value lists [1, 4].

In summary, DS-Picklist has higher joint accuracy than DS-DST, and both models show significant improvements in slot accuracy for specific slots, particularly those with values that are not easily extracted from the dialog context.

For example, in the table that list the top-10 slots, according to the ratio of ground-truth slot values which cannot be found through span matching [3], we can observe a error reduction for some slots such as attraction-type, hotel-internet and hotel-parking [3, 5].

DeClarE's performance varies across datasets and configurations, showcasing its adaptability and the impact of its different components.

On the Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, DeClarE, particularly in its "Full" configuration, demonstrates strong performance. For Snopes, DeClarE (Full) achieved a Macro F1-score of 0.79 and an AUC of 0.86 [6, 7]. It is slightly lower than the Distant Supervision configuration [6]. On the PolitiFact dataset, DeClarE outperforms all the baseline models by a margin of 7.9% AUC [7]. The performance across different DeClarE configurations on both Snopes and PolitiFact highlights the value of external evidence and the contributions of the biLSTM, attention mechanism, and source embeddings [6, 7].
![Performance of model configurations on Snopes and PolitiFact datasets](image3)

In contrast, on the NewsTrust dataset, the focus shifts to credibility regression, evaluated using Mean Squared Error (MSE) [10]. DeClarE (Full) exhibits the best performance with the lowest MSE of 0.29, indicating a 17% decrease in MSE compared to the best-performing baselines [9]. The DeClarE (Plain) model, without attention and source embeddings, performs worse, underlining the importance of these components [9].
![Comparison of model configurations on NewsTrust dataset](image1)

For the SemEval dataset, the task involves both credibility classification and confidence scoring [5]. Here, DeClarE (Full) again leads with the highest Macro Accuracy of 0.57 and the lowest RMSE of 0.604, showcasing its effectiveness in this dual-objective task [5].
![Performance of model configurations on SemEval dataset](image2)

In summary, DeClarE consistently performs well across all datasets, with the "Full" configuration generally achieving the best results, highlighting the effectiveness of its comprehensive approach.

The analysis reveals several key differences between the LANI and CHAI datasets in terms of task completion and performance metrics.

First, let's look at the dataset characteristics. LANI has more paragraphs (6,000) than CHAI (1,596). CHAI, however, has more instructions per paragraph (7.70) compared to LANI (4.7). This indicates that CHAI instructions are generally more complex, involving multiple steps.  The average actions per instruction also reflect this, with CHAI having 54.5 actions compared to LANI's 24.6.
![The dataset characteristics of LANI and CHAI](image1)

The linguistic analysis shows difference in using spatial language.
![The linguistic categories of LANI and CHAI](image3)

In terms of performance, different metrics are used. For LANI, Stop Distance (SD) and Task Completion (TC) are used, while for CHAI, SD and Manipulation Accuracy (MA) are employed [6]. This difference reflects the nature of the tasks – LANI focuses on navigation, while CHAI includes manipulation of objects [9].

The performance of various methods is compared in the table, that present result of development.
![The method comparision of LANI and CHAI in development](image4)

However, the performance difference is more pronounced on LANI [5, 8].
![The method comparision of LANI and CHAI in test](image5)

Human performance also differs between the two datasets. On LANI, humans achieve a successful task completion rate of 63%, while on CHAI, manipulation accuracy is 100% [2]. This suggests that while manipulation in CHAI is relatively straightforward for humans, the navigation aspect of LANI presents more ambiguity [2, 4].

In summary, the key differences are that LANI focuses on navigation with simpler instructions, achieving higher task completion, while CHAI involves more complex instructions combining navigation and manipulation, with performance measured by manipulation accuracy.

In summary, the presence of certain linguistic categories significantly affects goal prediction error, and the proposed approach, while competitive, still has a gap compared to human performance in instruction execution.

The performances on the GLUE benchmark vary significantly between BERT models and CNN models. Generally, BERT models outperform CNN models across most tasks.

Specifically, `BERT_BASE` and `BERT_LARGE` achieve higher scores than `CNN Base` and `CNN Large` in tasks such as CoLA, MRPC, QQP, MNLI, QNLI, and RTE [9]. For instance, `BERT_LARGE` exhibits notably high performance on CoLA, QNLI, and RTE, showcasing its superior capability in handling a diverse range of language understanding tasks  ![Comparison of Model Performance on NLP Tasks](image2).

However, it is also noted that while CNN models might perform adequately in aggregate, they may fall short on tasks involving sentence pairs compared to models like STILTs and BERT [9].This suggests that BERT's architecture, which trains on entire paragraphs as opposed to just two sentences like the CNN base model[6], is more effective for tasks requiring an understanding of relationships between sentences.

In summary, BERT models generally outperform CNN models on the GLUE benchmark, particularly in tasks that involve understanding relationships between sentence pairs.

The text provides information on the performance of CNN models with and without fine-tuning or stacking architectures.

Experiments were conducted, and it was shown that it is possible to stack task-specific architectures for NER and constituency parsing on top of the pre-trained representations, achieving new state-of-the-art performance levels for both tasks [2]. Two ways of stacking were evaluated: (1) ELMo-style, where the pretrained models are not fine-tuned but are linearly combined at different depths, and (2) with fine-tuning, where different learning rates are set for the task-specific [6]. Both methods outperform the previous state of the art, but fine-tuning gives the biggest gain [1]. For structured prediction tasks like named entity recognition and parsing, task-specific architectures are fine-tuned together with the language model but with different learning rates [7]. The input to these architectures are the output representations of the pretrained language model [7].
The CNN base model performs as well as STILTs in aggregate; however, on some tasks involving sentence-pairs, STILTs performs much better (MRPC, RTE) [5].

In conclusion, CNN models generally perform better with fine-tuning and stacking architectures, especially for tasks involving structured predictions and sentence-pairs.

The amount of training data has a significant impact on the GLUE score, and this effect varies across different datasets. Generally, more training data leads to increased accuracy [10]. Specifically, performance continues to improve with up to 18B tokens, and it is suggested that more data would likely further enhance performance [5, 10].

The graph illustrating this relationship shows a positive correlation between the amount of Common Crawl data used for pretraining and the average GLUE score achieved.  ![The trend in the graph shows an upward progression, suggesting that more pretraining data typically leads to better performance.](image5)

Different data sources also result in varied effectiveness on different tasks. For instance, BooksCorpus and Wikipedia perform very well on QNLI and MNLI but less well on other tasks [2]. When comparing Common Crawl and News Crawl data, the former generally performs better, even on tasks like MRPC, which is newswire-based [4]. This difference is likely because News Crawl examples are individual sentences, while Common Crawl examples consist of several sentences, which are more effective for end-tasks based on sentence pairs [4].

![The table presents performance metrics of language models trained on different datasets and with varying amounts of training data.](image1)

In summary, increasing the amount of training data generally improves the GLUE score, but the specific impact varies depending on the dataset and the nature of the training examples.

The data provided allows us to analyze the impact of both the amount and type of pretraining data, as well as the modeling approach used, on the performance of various NLP tasks.

Increasing the amount of pretraining data generally improves performance. This is evident in the graph showing a positive correlation between the volume of Common Crawl data (in tokens) and the average GLUE score. ![The trend in the graph shows an upward progression, suggesting that more pretraining data typically leads to better performance.](image4) This aligns with the statement that "more data for pretraining improves performance, keeping everything else equal" [4]. Specifically, the model's performance increases with up to 18 billion tokens of Common Crawl data, and it is suggested that performance would likely continue to improve with even more data [7, 8].

The type of pretraining data, its structure, and its source. Pretraining on corpora with paragraph structure is more beneficial than using only individual sentences [4]. This is shown with the News Crawl data (individual sentences) generally performs worse than Common Crawl (multiple sentences or paragraphs). [5] shows detailed statistics on different training data. ![The table presents the performance of various models on a set of NLP tasks.](image3)

The choice of modeling approach ("cloze," "bilm," or a combination) also impacts the results. The "cloze" loss, which predicts the center word given its context, performs significantly better than the "bilm" loss, which predicts left and right context tokens separately [1]. Combining the two loss types does not yield improvements over using the cloze loss alone [1, 8]. It also shows specific scores of the performance. ![Performance values are numerical scores indicating the efficacy of the model on the respective task for each modeling approach.](image5)

In summary, combining larger, structured pretraining data with a cloze-style modeling approach yields the best performance on the evaluated NLP tasks.

The impact of aligning word embeddings on BLEU scores varies depending on the specific language translation task. In some cases, alignment is not beneficial, with gains or losses being insignificant [8]. Specifically, when examining the effect of word embedding alignment, the results indicate that a priori alignment of embeddings may not be necessary [8].

![The table shows different datasets with scores for "unaligned" and "aligned" categories.](image3)

For instance, in translations from Galician (GL), Portuguese (PT), Azerbaijani (AZ), Turkish (TR), Belarusian (BE), and Russian (RU) to English (EN), the alignment of word embeddings did not consistently improve the BLEU scores [8]. The changes in BLEU scores when using aligned versus unaligned embeddings were minimal across all languages. For example, GL→EN had a change of -1.3, PT→EN -0.2, and RU→EN +0.3 [8].

However, in multilingual systems, aligning word embeddings can help increase BLEU scores [7].
![The table presents evaluation metrics for different training and evaluation setups involving language pairs.](image2)
When a single encoder is used for multiple source languages, aligning ensures that word embeddings are in similar vector spaces, which simplifies the learning process for the model [7]. This effect is shown that aligning the word embeddings helps to increase the BLEU scores for all three tasks(GL+PT evaluated on GL, AZ+TR evaluated on AZ, BE+RU evaluated on BE) [7].

In summary, the alignment of word embeddings does not always improve BLEU scores in bilingual systems but can be beneficial in multilingual systems.

Pre-training generally improves translation accuracy, especially for words with low frequency in the training corpus [1].

![Pre-training improves translation accuracy for the entire vocabulary, but especially for low-frequency words.](image2)

The effect of pre-training is also influenced by the similarity between the languages in the translation pair [3, 10]. Specifically, the gains in translation accuracy are roughly in order of their similarity, pre-training and alignment ensures that the word embeddings of the two source languages are put into similar vector spaces [3].
Multilingual translation systems that use the pre-trained embeddings also see the positive effect [6].
When applying pre-trained embeddings, the gains in each translation pair are roughly in order of their similarity, with GL/PT showing the largest gains, and BE/RU showing a small decrease [3].

![Effect of pre-training on multilingual translation into English.](image5)

It is also noted that aligning word embeddings helps increase BLEU scores for all three tasks in multilingual scenarios, as it allows the model to learn in a similar fashion as if training on a single language [3].
Training set size plays a crucial role. Gains from pre-training are highest when the baseline system is poor but not too poor, typically with a baseline BLEU score in the range of 3-4 [9]. All language pairs were trained on 40,000 sentences to avoid the effects of the training set size [5].

In conclusion, pre-training improves translation accuracy, particularly for less frequent words, with the effect being more pronounced in similar language pairs and when a moderate amount of training data is available.

The effect of aligning word embeddings on translation performance varies across different language pairs. In bilingual systems, aligning word embeddings doesn't show consistent improvement [5]. For example, in the GL → EN (Galician to English) and PT → EN (Portuguese to English) pairs, alignment slightly decreased performance, while it marginally improved for AZ → EN (Azerbaijani to English) and RU → EN (Russian to English) [4].

![The table shows different datasets with scores for "unaligned" and "aligned" categories.](image4)

However, in multilingual systems, aligning word embeddings generally improves performance [7].

![The table presents evaluation metrics for different training and evaluation setups involving language pairs.](image3)

Pre-training manages to improve the accuracy of translation for the entire vocabulary, but particularly for words that are of low frequency in the training corpus [8].

![The image is a bar chart comparing F-measure scores of target words based on their frequency in a training corpus.](image2)

Pre-training can also affect qualitative aspects of translation, such as capturing rarer vocabulary and generating more grammatically well-formed sentences [4].
![The table shows four rows with text related to a translation or transcription task:](image1)

In summary, word embedding alignment's impact on translation varies; it slightly decreases performance in some bilingual systems while improving it in multilingual ones, and pre-training improves translation accuracy, especially for low-frequency words.

The impact of removing specific components on model performance is detailed in the provided data.

First, the removal of the R-GCN component significantly reduces performance. Specifically, "if we then remove R-GCN (GloVe w/o R-GCN in Table 3), we lose 8.0 points" [2]. This is further supported by the performance drop from 62.4 (unmasked) and 63.2 (masked) for "No R-GCN" to 51.2 (unmasked) and 11.6 (masked) for "GloVe w/o R-GCN" [10].
![The table shows R-GCN component significantly reduces performance](image1)

The ablation of relation types also affects performance. When all nodes are fully connected without distinguishing edges by type ("No relation types" in Table 3), there are only marginal improvements compared to using ELMo alone ("No R-GCN" in Table 3) [9].

Removing specific relation types like DOC-BASED, MATCH, and COREF impacts performance differently. The model utilizes DOC-BASED connections more than MATCH or COREF connections because most connections are between mentions in the same document [1]. Removing DOC-BASED connections ("No DOC–BASED") results in performance of 62.9 (unmasked) and 65.8 (masked) [10]. Removing MATCH connections ("No MATCH") leads to performance of 64.3 (unmasked) and 67.4 (masked). The removal of coreference links ("No COREF") has a more marginal role, as the MATCH heuristic already captures the easiest coreference cases [1].

In summary, removing the R-GCN component drastically reduces performance, removing relation types yields marginal improvements, and the impact of removing specific relation types varies, with DOC-BASED connections being the most crucial.

The impact of coreference information on Entity-GCN models varies between unmasked and masked settings.

In the unmasked setting, the model achieves a development accuracy of 65.3 with coreference and 64.8 without it [4]. However, coreference links and complement edges seem to play a more marginal role [6]. In the masked setting, the model achieves a development accuracy of 70.5, but the text doesn't explicitly state the performance without coreference in this setting [4]. The text mentions that "Since Entity-GCN seems to gain little advantage using the coreference system, we report test results both with and without using it. Surprisingly, with coreference, we observe performance degradation on the test set" [6].
![Comparative performance of different model configurations](image4)
It is mentioned that coreference links are easier to recover in the masked setting than in the unmasked setting [10].

Overall, coreference information has a mixed impact on the performance, with a slight improvement in the unmasked development set, potential degradation in the unmasked test set, and an unspecified impact on the masked setting.

The DyGIE system demonstrates significant improvements in both entity recognition and relation extraction across various datasets and domains [9]. Specifically, on the ACE04 and ACE05 datasets, DyGIE achieves relative improvements of 7.1% and 7.0% on NER, and 25.8% and 13.7% on relation extraction, respectively, compared to the state-of-the-art (SOTA) [9].

For overlapping entity extraction, DyGIE also shows strong results on the ACE04-O and ACE05-O datasets, with improvements of 11.6% and 11.3% respectively [2].
![Ablations on the ACE05 development set with different graph propagation setups.](image1)
The effects of propagation layers vary: coreference propagation generally benefits entity extraction, while relation propagation has a more substantial impact on relation extraction [1, 4]. For example, relation propagation provides significant advantages in both entity and relation extraction in both ACE05 and SciERC datasets [1]. In contrast, coreference propagation shows a small benefit on both tasks for SciIE but can sometimes hurt relation extraction on ACE05 [1]. The optimal number of iterations for coreference propagation in the entity extraction task is observed to be two (N=2) [7]. In some cases, like in ACE05 the best entity extraction results achieved by given the priority to Relation Propagation over Coreference Propagation [9].

In summary, DyGIE significantly improves performance on both entity and relation extraction across different datasets, with coreference propagation mainly benefiting entity extraction and relation propagation significantly improving relation extraction.

DYGIE achieves substantial improvements in both entity recognition and relation extraction across various datasets and domains [4]. Specifically, on the ACE04 and ACE05 datasets, DYGIE shows relative improvements of 7.1% and 7.0% over the state of the art on Named Entity Recognition (NER) [4].
![DYGIE performance comparison across datasets](image1)
For relation extraction, DYGIE achieves a 25.8% relative improvement over the state of the art (SOTA) on ACE04 and a 13.7% relative improvement on ACE05 [4]. On the SciERC dataset, DYGIE improves the state of the art by 5.9% for relation extraction and 1.9% for NER [8].

Coreference propagation primarily benefits entity extraction, whereas relation propagation significantly benefits both entity and relation extraction [6]. The coreference layer obtains the best performance on the second iteration (N=2) [5]. Relation propagation is particularly helpful in scenarios with multiple relation instances across different entities, as seen in both ACE05 and SciERC datasets [6].

The performance of the DyGIE system varies across different datasets, with significant improvements in both entity and relation extraction, and coreference and relation propagation have distinct positive impacts on these tasks.

The DyGIE model demonstrates varied performance across different datasets and configurations for entity and relation extraction tasks.

On the ACE04-O and ACE05-O datasets, DyGIE significantly improves upon the state-of-the-art, with increases of 11.6% and 11.3%, respectively [2]. On the GENIA dataset, the improvement is more modest at 1.5% [2]. These results indicate that DyGIE is effective for information extraction across various domains with overlapped entities, particularly in biomedicine [2].

The model was also evaluated on the ACE2004, ACE2005, and GENIA datasets, there is no coreference. [4]

For the auxiliary coreference task with ACE05, the model achieves a competitive coreference test set performance of 70.4 F1 [5].

Relation propagation significantly improves performance, especially in sentences with more entities, indicating that broader context utilization is beneficial [3].

The CorefProp and RelProp components play distinct roles:
*   **CorefProp (Coreference Propagation)**: On ACE05, coreference propagation primarily benefits entity extraction but can negatively impact relation extraction [9]. In the SciERC dataset, CorefProp has a minimal effect on entity extraction performance because pronouns are uniformly labeled as "Generic" [6, 7].
*   **RelProp (Relation Propagation)**: Relation propagation significantly benefits both entity and relation extraction in both ACE05 and SciERC datasets [9].

In summary, DyGIE's performance varies across datasets, with significant improvements in overlapping entity extraction. Coreference propagation benefits entity extraction on some datasets, while relation propagation consistently enhances both entity and relation extraction.

The impact of coreference annotations on DyGIE's entity recognition performance varies across datasets.

In the SciERC dataset, coreference propagation (CorefProp) doesn't significantly affect entity extraction because pronouns are uniformly labeled as "Generic" [9].
![Effect of number of iterations for coreference propagation](image1)
This suggests that when pronoun disambiguation isn't a challenge, coreference information provides limited benefit. The coreference layer achieves the best performance on the second iteration (N=2) [6].

However, in datasets like ACE05, where pronoun entity class disambiguation is crucial and requires cross-sentence context, coreference propagation significantly improves performance [10].
![The effect of the coreference layer for entity categorization of pronouns](image2)
For example, identifying whether "them" and "ours" refer to a person (PER) or organization (ORG) often necessitates examining previous sentences. DyGIE achieves a 6.6% improvement in pronoun performance on ACE05, showcasing coreference propagation's utility in such contexts [10].

In conclusion, the presence of coreference annotations improves DyGIE's performance in entity recognition, particularly when pronoun disambiguation requires cross-sentence reasoning, but has minimal effect when pronoun categories are uniform.

The impact of the number of iterations in CorefProp and RelProp on F1 scores can be observed in the line graphs. ![Effect of Iterations on F1 Scores](image5) For entity extraction, the CorefProp achieves the best performance on the second iteration (N=2) [2]. Similarly, for relation extraction, the RelProp achieves the best performance on the second iteration (M=2) [4]. This suggests that two iterations are optimal for both processes, after which performance likely begins to degrade.

In comparison, The line graph shows the relationship between the number of entities in a sentence and the Relation F1 score. ![Relation F1 Score vs. Number of Entities](image4)
As the number of entities in a sentence increases, the Relation F1 score for both DyGIE and DyGIE-RelProp decreases [image4].

In summary, the optimal number of iterations for both CorefProp and RelProp is two, while the Relation F1 score decreases as the number of entities in a sentence increases.

The effect of different iterations of CorefProp and RelProp on F1 scores varies for entity and relation extraction tasks.

For entity extraction, the best performance is achieved on the second iteration (N=2) of coreference propagation [2]. The image shows how Entity F1 scores change with the number of iterations for CorefProp, with the highest score at two iterations.
![Entity F1 peaks at the second iteration of CorefProp.](image5)
For relation extraction, the model also achieves the best performance on the second iteration (M=2) of relation propagation [8].
![Relation F1 peaks at the second iteration of RelProp.](image5)
Relation propagation achieves significant improvement in sentences with more entities [5]. However, as the number of entities in a sentence increases, the performance of both "DyGIE" and "DyGIE-RelProp" systems decreases. Nonetheless, "DyGIE" generally outperforms "DyGIE-RelProp" across all categories of entity numbers.
![Relation extraction performance decreases as the number of entities increases.](image3)

In summary, the optimal number of iterations for both CorefProp and RelProp is two, and while relation propagation improves performance in sentences with more entities, the overall F1 score decreases as the number of entities increases.

Let's analyze the performance comparison between Simple Word-Embedding-based Models (SWEMs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) across various datasets and subspace dimensions.

On topic prediction tasks, SWEM demonstrates stronger performances than both LSTM and CNN compositional architectures [7]. Specifically, the SWEM-concat model even outperforms a 29-layer deep CNN model in topic prediction [7].

When examining model complexity using subspace training, SWEM shows significantly higher accuracy than CNN for a large range of low subspace dimensions, indicating that SWEM is more parameter-efficient to get a decent solution [3].
![Accuracy Comparison on AG News](image1)
However, CNN can leverage more trainable parameters to achieve higher accuracy when the subspace dimension is large [3].

For sentence-classification tasks, SWEM yields inferior accuracies on sentiment analysis datasets compared to CNN/LSTM models [10]. But, SWEM exhibits comparable performance on other tasks like subjectivity classification (Subj) and question classification (TREC), with fewer parameters and faster training [10].
![Performance on Sentence Classification](image3)

In sequence matching tasks, including natural language inference and answer sentence selection, SWEM shows the best results compared to CNN or LSTM encoders on most datasets except WikiQA [1].
![Experimental Results on NLP Tasks](image2)
On the SNLI dataset, SWEM-max performs the best among all SWEM variants [1].

Hierarchical pooling in SWEM (SWEM-hier) is more suitable for Chinese text classification, taking spatial information into account, and implying that Chinese is more sensitive to local word-order features than English [8].

In summary, SWEMs generally outperform or are comparable to CNNs in topic prediction and sequence matching, especially in lower subspace dimensions, while CNNs may perform better in sentiment analysis and when leveraging more parameters in higher subspace dimensions.

The inclusion of different components in the model has varying effects on performance across datasets D1, D2, D3, and D4, as shown in the ablation tests [7]. Transfer learning is generally helpful, with improvements observed even when only one layer is transferred. The transfer of the LSTM and embedding layers is generally more beneficial than transferring only the output layer [7].
![Ablation study results of transferring different components from the document-level model to the aspect-level model.](image2)
Specifically, transferring the embedding layer is more helpful on datasets D3 and D4, possibly due to their unbalanced label distributions [7].

When varying the percentage of document-level training examples, there's a stable improvement in accuracy across all datasets as the number of document examples increases [5].
![Performance changes with varying percentages of document-level training examples.](image3)
The Macro-F1 scores also generally improve, with sharp increases observed for D3 and D4 when the percentage changes from 0 to 0.4 [5]. This is likely because dataset D3 and D4 has very small neutral examples in test sets, small prediction difference will bring large differences [2]. The number of data entries for these datasets, divided into positive, negative, and neutral categories for both training and testing sets, can influence the model's performance, particularly in cases of imbalanced data distribution [7].
![Dataset statistics, showing the number of positive, negative, and neutral entries for training and test sets across four datasets.](image1)

In summary, transferring LSTM and embedding layers is generally more effective than the output layer, with embedding layer transfer being particularly beneficial for datasets with unbalanced label distributions, and increasing the percentage of document-level training examples generally improves both accuracy and Macro-F1 scores.

The TRADE model demonstrates strong performance across multiple domains in the MultiWOZ dataset. It achieves the highest joint goal accuracy of 48.62% and a slot accuracy of 96.92% on the full dataset [6]. Specifically, on the restaurant domain, TRADE achieves a joint goal accuracy of 65.35% [8, 3].
```markdown
![The table presents the performance of different models on the MultiWOZ dataset, both for the full dataset and for a subset focusing only on restaurant-related dialogues.](image2)
```
This outperforms other models such as MDBT, GLAD, GCE, and SpanPtr [9, 7]. The superior performance is attributed to TRADE's use of a copy mechanism, which facilitates knowledge transfer when predicting (domain, slot, value) triplets [3].
```markdown
![The table presents a breakdown of different "Slots" and data distribution for five categories: Hotel, Train, Attraction, Restaurant, and Taxi.](image1)
```

In zero-shot settings, where the model is tested on unseen domains without any prior training on them, TRADE also shows promising results [3].
```markdown
![The table presents data comparing "Trained Single" and "Zero-Shot" performance across five categories: Hotel, Train, Attraction, Restaurant, and Taxi.](image3)
```
For instance, it achieves a joint goal accuracy of 60.58% in one of the zero-shot domains (Taxi) [3]. While zero-shot performance is lower than trained performance, it still indicates a strong ability to generalize to new domains [1].

In summary, the TRADE model demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on the MultiWOZ dataset across multiple domains, and also shows significant capability in zero-shot scenarios, highlighting its transferability and adaptability.

The TRADE model demonstrates superior performance on the MultiWOZ dataset. Specifically, it achieves the highest joint goal accuracy of 48.62% and a slot accuracy of 96.92% [10].
![TRADE achieves the highest performance, 48.62% on joint goal accuracy and 96.92% on slot accuracy, on MultiWOZ](image2)
This surpasses models like MDBT, GLAD, and GCE, which rely on predefined domain ontologies for binary classification, hindering their performance [10].

When expanding to a new domain, fine-tuning the TRADE model yields better results than training from scratch [6, 7, 8].
![Domain expansion results using different strategies](image3)
Fine-tuning strategies, with a focus on mitigating catastrophic forgetting, show that GEM (Gradient Episodic Memory) outperforms naive and EWC (Elastic Weight Consolidation) fine-tuning [8, 9]. This is evident in maintaining performance on the original domains while adapting to the new one [9].

In zero-shot scenarios, while performance varies across domains, the taxi domain shows remarkably high zero-shot performance, nearing that achieved with full training data [3].
![Zero-shot DST results on MultiWOZ dataset](image4)
This is attributed to shared slot values with the training domain [3]. However, for unique slots within a domain, the model struggles in zero-shot scenarios [1].

In summary, TRADE outperforms other models in joint and slot accuracy on MultiWOZ, excels in domain adaptation with fine-tuning, especially using GEM, and exhibits high zero-shot performance in specific domains with shared slot values.

Domain expansion experiments were conducted by excluding one domain and fine-tuning on that domain [9]. The evaluation considered two main aspects: performance on the four pre-trained domains and performance on the new domain [6].

When fine-tuning on a new domain, GEM generally outperforms Naive and EWC fine-tuning in terms of overcoming catastrophic forgetting on the original four domains [6, 9]. For example, fine-tuning with GEM maintains higher performance on the original domains compared to naive fine-tuning [5].
![Domain Expansion Evaluation Table](image3)
Specifically, the performance drop on the four domains after fine-tuning with GEM is significantly less than with naive fine-tuning [5].

Elastic Weight Consolidation (EWC) uses the diagonal of the Fisher information matrix as a regularizer [3]. Gradient Episodic Memory (GEM), on the other hand, keeps a small number of samples from the source domains and applies a constraint on the gradient to prevent the loss on the stored samples from increasing [8].

Fine-tuning from the base model usually achieves better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch [9]. For example, fine-tuning the TRADE model achieves better joint accuracy than training from scratch, even when using only 1% of the new domain data [2].
![Zero-Shot DST Error Analysis](image2)
Regarding slot similarities, certain slots demonstrate successful knowledge transfer, while others, particularly those unique to a single domain, are harder to track correctly [7]. The cosine similarity between slot embeddings reveals that slots with similar or correlated values tend to have higher similarity, which affects their performance in zero-shot scenarios [7].
![Cosine Similarity Heatmap of Slot Embeddings](image5)

In summary, GEM outperforms EWC and naive fine-tuning in domain expansion by better preserving performance on pre-trained domains and achieving superior results on new domains, while slot similarity, as indicated by cosine similarity, influences the model's ability to transfer knowledge effectively.

The analysis of various commercial machine translation (MT) systems reveals significant differences in translation accuracy and gender bias across different languages [9]. The performance metrics used to evaluate these systems include overall gender accuracy (Acc), the difference in performance (F1 score) between masculine and feminine scores (ΔG), and the difference in performance (F1 score) between pro-stereotypical and anti-stereotypical gender role assignments (ΔS) [4].

A key finding is that all tested MT systems exhibit gender bias, with performance deteriorating when translating anti-stereotypical roles (e.g., a male receptionist) compared to pro-stereotypical roles (e.g., a female nurse) [1]. This trend is consistent across various languages. For instance, Google Translate shows higher accuracy for stereotypical translations compared to non-stereotypical ones across all tested languages [1]:

![Google Translate's performance on gender translation for different languages.](image3)

The detailed performance metrics of different commercial MT systems, including Google Translate, Microsoft Translator, Amazon Translate, and SYSTRAN, are presented across several languages:

![Performance metrics of different commercial MT systems.](image2)

The overall accuracy varies significantly among systems and languages [8, 4]. For example, Microsoft Translator achieves its highest accuracy on German (74.1%), while Amazon Translate performs best on Spanish (59.4%) [4]. The ΔG and ΔS metrics indicate varying degrees of gender bias, with higher numbers suggesting stronger biases [4].

Additionally, the data is categorized by gender classification across datasets like Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT. The performance differences among these systems are that machine translation systems have much higher accuracies with pro-stereotypical translations [10]:

![Breakdown of data across three categories (Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT) by gender classification (Male, Female, Neutral).](image1)

The comparison shows that machine translation systems are significantly prone to gender-biased translation errors, with performance varying considerably across different languages and systems [5].

In conclusion, machine translation systems show varying accuracy and significant gender bias across different languages, with a general trend of higher accuracy for stereotypical gender roles.

The impact of stereotype-based adjustments on machine translation (MT) gender bias accuracy varies across different languages. Introducing adjectives that reinforce gender stereotypes, such as "handsome" for males and "pretty" for females, can improve translation accuracy and reduce bias in some languages [8].

For instance, adding stereotypical adjectives significantly improved performance in Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian [8]. Specifically, the accuracy increased by 10.4% for Spanish, 11.2% for Russian, and 4.5% for Ukrainian when such adjectives were added.
![Gender prediction accuracy improvements with stereotypical adjectives](image2)

However, this approach is not universally effective and is considered an impractical general debiasing scheme because it assumes oracle coreference resolution [8]. It does demonstrate the relationship between coreference resolution and MT, serving as an indicator of gender bias in MT [8].
![Examples of adding](image3)

Furthermore, all tested MT systems show significantly better performance when presented with pro-stereotypical assignments (e.g., a female nurse) compared to anti-stereotypical roles (e.g., a male receptionist) [2].
![Google Translate accuracy on stereotypical vs. non-stereotypical gender roles](image1)

In summary, stereotype-based adjustments can improve gender bias accuracy in machine translation for some languages, but the effectiveness varies, and the method is not a practical solution for all cases.

Different training and evaluation strategies significantly impact F1 scores in question-answering tasks. Adversarial training, for example, involves using adversarial distractors during training, which can improve the model's robustness. When trained on standard distractors and tested on adversarial distractors, the F1 score drops; however, retraining with adversarial distractors increases the F1 score [9].

![Performance with different training and evaluation data](image4)

Specifically, training on adversarial distractors and then evaluating on the same can lead to an F1 score of 60.10, compared to 46.84 when trained on original distractors [10]. This is further show that when add filtering by entity type, the model trained on the adversarially selected distractors can recover most of its original accuracy (increases to 58.42 F1) [6].

In the open-domain setting, adding gold standard paragraphs significantly improves the F1 score.

![Impact of Gold Paragraphs on Open-Domain F1 Scores](image2)

For instance, the F1 score goes from 39.12 with 500 retrieved paragraphs to 53.12 when the gold paragraphs are included [5].
In addition, in terms of question types, single-hop questions generally have higher F1 scores compared to multi-hop questions.

![F1 Scores for Different Question Types](image3)

For example, single-hop questions achieve an F1 score of 70.54, while multi-hop questions have an F1 score of 54.46 [image3].

In summary, training and evaluation strategies have a significant effect on F1 scores, with adversarial training and the inclusion of gold standard data leading to improvements, and single-hop questions outperforming multi-hop ones.

The introduction of adversarial data significantly alters the performance of BERT models on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT) dataset. Initially, BERT's peak performance on the original dataset was impressively high, reaching 77%, just three points below the average untrained human baseline [8]. However, this performance was found to be misleading due to the model's exploitation of spurious statistical cues within the dataset [8].

To construct the adversarial dataset, for each data, the claim was negated and the label inverted [2]. This is shown with an example about Google as a monopoly:
![The table presents a comparison between "Original" and "Adversarial" viewpoints concerning whether Google is a harmful monopoly.](image3)

When models were trained and evaluated on this adversarial dataset, which eliminated these cues, BERT's performance dropped dramatically [6]. Specifically, BERT's peak performance reduced to 53%, with the mean and median performances around 50% [6].
![The table presents a comparison of the performance metrics for different BERT models, based on their test performance.](image4)
This indicates that on the adversarial dataset, the models, including BERT, performed essentially at random [3].

The significant drop in performance after applying the adversarial data setup demonstrates that the original high performance of BERT was not due to genuine argument comprehension [7]. Instead, the model was leveraging superficial patterns or cues in the data [8].

The conclusion is that the adversarial dataset provides a more robust evaluation of argument comprehension, and BERT learned nothing about argument comprehension [7].

The performance of different COMET decoding methods varies significantly when generating commonsense inferences. Greedy decoding performs the best among the automated methods, achieving an average score of 77.53 across all relation types. However, this is still lower than human validation, which averages 86.18. Other decoding methods like beam search and random sampling show lower performance compared to greedy decoding.
![The table presents the performance of different decoding methods used in the COMET framework for generating commonsense inferences, evaluated against a human baseline on the ATOMIC dataset. Each row represents one specific decoding method or human validation, and each column corresponds to a different types of commonsense relation: oEffect, oReact, oWant, xAttr, xEffect, xIntent, xNeed, xReact, xWant, and Avg (average performance across all relations).](image1)

The model COMET is able to generate novel knowledge that humans rate as high quality, with up to 77.5% (ATOMIC) and 91.7% (ConceptNet) precision at top 1, which approaches human performance for these resources [3].

When it comes to variations in training data percentages, using a higher percentage of training data generally improves the model's performance metrics.
![The table displays the results of different training data percentages on model performance metrics.](image3)
Full training data ("FULL train") results in the lowest perplexity (11.13) and the highest BLEU-2 score (14.34) [3]. Even with only 10% of the training data, the model is still able to produce generations that are coherent, adequate, and novel [8].

In conclusion, greedy decoding is the best COMET decoding method, but human validation is superior, and model performance generally improves with more training data.

COMET demonstrates superior performance across several metrics on the ConceptNet dataset. It achieves the lowest perplexity (4.32), the highest score (95.25), and the closest approximation to human performance (91.69) [3, 7].
![Performance comparison of different models on ConceptNet](image1)
This indicates high model confidence in its predictions and that the generated tuples are frequently deemed correct [10].

A human evaluation confirms that 91.7% of greedily decoded tuples generated by COMET are rated as correct [7, 10].
The model also exhibits a high degree of novelty, with 59.25% of the generated tuples not being present in the training set [1].
![Classifier accuracy and novel tuples percentage at various edit distances](image2)
This novelty extends to creating new nodes, with 3.75% of 'o' nodes being novel [1]. For example, COMET can generate the tuple "mango IsA fruit," even when such a tuple is absent from the training set. This contrasts with less informed models, like COMET (-pretrain), which might incorrectly infer "mango IsA spice" [2].

In summary, COMET is highly effective on the ConceptNet dataset, producing high-quality, novel knowledge tuples with accuracy approaching human performance.

The sensitivity and word error rate (WER) vary significantly between closed and open vocabulary models under different backoff strategies, as illustrated in the provided data.

In closed vocabulary (word-only) models, the "Neutral" backoff strategy results in the lowest sensitivity and WER [4]. Specifically, the "Neutral" strategy has a sensitivity of 11.3 for all attack types, matching its WER [2]. The "Pass-Through" strategy has slightly higher sensitivity and WER (11.3) compared to "Neutral", while "Background" exhibits the highest sensitivity(13.1) and WER [2].

! [The table presents data comparing different models with respect to various criteria.](image2)

In open vocabulary models (char/word+char/word-piece), the "Neutral" backoff strategy again achieves the lowest sensitivity and WER [4]. The "Pass-Through" strategy shows significantly higher sensitivity, with an overall sensitivity and WER score of 30.3, and Background is (14.7) [2]. "Background" strategy has lower sensitivity than "Pass-through" but higher than "Neutral" [2].

Furthermore, we can see the trade-off between WER and sensitivity, visualizing in figure 2 [10].

! [The image consists of two scatter plots, each representing the relationship between sensitivity and word error rate (WER) for two types of models: word-only models (left plot) and char-only models (right plot).](image4)

In summary, the "Neutral" backoff strategy consistently demonstrates the lowest sensitivity and WER across both closed and open vocabulary models, while "Pass-Through" generally results in the highest sensitivity, especially in open vocabulary settings.

$BiDAF$ and FastQA are two models that were tested on various datasets [10]. Let's examine their comparative performance.

In the standard test setting for WIKI HOP, $BiDAF$ achieved an accuracy of 42.9% (test) and 49.7% (test*), while FastQA scored 25.7% (test) and 27.2% (test*) [image4]. However, in the masked setting, $BiDAF$'s performance dropped to 33.7% (test) and 42.9% (test*), while FastQA scored 31.3% (test) and 30.6% (test*), which indicates BiDAF still generally outperformed FastQA, but the difference was less pronounced, and even reversed in the test* condition. [image4].

When evaluated using only documents leading to the correct answer (gold chain), $BiDAF$ consistently outperformed FastQA across both datasets and test conditions [7, image4].

Experiments show that $BiDAF$ is able to leverage cross-document information. [9].
![Performance metrics of different models](image1)
Overall, $BiDAF$ generally outperforms FastQA across both WIKI HOP and MEDHOP datasets in most test conditions, particularly in the standard and gold chain setups.

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models varies across the WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets under different test conditions.

In the standard setup, BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA on both datasets [4].

For instance, under the "gold chain" condition, BiDAF achieves significantly higher scores than FastQA on both WIKIHOP (81.2% vs 65.3% on the masked test) and MEDHOP (99.3% vs 51.8% on the masked test) [7]. However, BiDAF consistently shows superior performance compared to FastQA, especially in the masked setting [1].
FastQA, with fewer latent connections than BiDAF, struggles to integrate cross-document information [3].

In conclusion, BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA across both WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets in various test conditions, particularly when multi-step reasoning is required.

The analysis of various methods reveals several key distinctions in word statistics, performance metrics, and human-like conversational abilities.

In terms of word statistics, Seq2Seq models tend to produce shorter sentences with more common words compared to human utterances [8]. The RetNRef models, particularly RetNRef++, improve upon this by increasing the use of rarer words, making their word statistics closer to human ones [8]. This is quantitatively shown in the comparison of word count, character count, and rare word percentages across different methods:
![Word Statistics Comparison](image3)
The RetNRef++ model's statistics are much closer to human ones, indicating a higher level of sophistication in language use compared to Seq2Seq [8].

Performance metrics show engagingness scores superior to Seq2Seq for all RetNRef variants, and with RetNRef++ slightly outperforming the retriever which it conditions on [9].
![Performance Metrics of Different Methods](image2)
RetNRef++ demonstrates the highest engagingness score (3.80) and maintains strong performance across other metrics, although it is slightly weaker in using the persona compared to Seq2Seq [9].

In comparative evaluations, RetNRef++ shows a significant win rate against other models like Memory Network and Seq2Seq:
![Comparative Evaluations](image1)
This indicates a preference for RetNRef++ in human evaluations, suggesting better conversational quality [image1].

Additionally, RetNRef++ demonstrates a high word overlap with the retriever output, meaning it effectively uses the retriever but can also generate novel content:
![Word Overlap Percentages](image4)
RetNRef++ has an over 80% word overlap with the retriever output around 53% of the time, showcasing its ability to balance retrieved content with original generation [1].

The engagingness improved model is shown performing well, and there are still issues that can be improved, such as repeated phrases [4].
![Example Dialogues](image5)

In conclusion, RetNRef++ stands out by combining the strengths of retrieval and generation models, achieving word statistics closer to human levels, superior engagingness scores, and a demonstrated ability to produce more nuanced and engaging conversations.

Berkshire Hathaway's financial performance from 2019 to 2021 can be analyzed through its stock repurchase program and net earnings across various segments.

Berkshire's common stock repurchase program allows the repurchase of Class A and Class B shares when the repurchase price is below Berkshire's intrinsic value [3, 4]. The program does not specify a maximum number of shares to be repurchased or obligate a specific repurchase amount, and the program is expected to continue indefinitely. [4, 6]. In 2021, Berkshire paid $27.1 billion to repurchase shares of its Class A and B common stock [4]. Details of the repurchases made during the fourth quarter of 2021 are available.
![Details of Class A and Class B common stock repurchased during the fourth quarter of 2021.](image2)

The net earnings attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders varied significantly across the years [1]:
![Net earnings attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders from 2019 to 2021.](image5)
- In 2019, net earnings were $81,417 million.
- In 2020, net earnings decreased to $42,521 million.
- In 2021, net earnings increased to $89,795 million.

Key segments contributing to these earnings include [1]:

*   **Insurance - Underwriting:** This segment showed consistent growth.
    *   2019: $325 million
    *   2020: $657 million
    *   2021: $728 million [2].
    Underwriting results included after-tax losses from significant catastrophe events.
*   **Insurance - Investment Income:** Earnings in this segment declined over the period [9].
    *   2019: $5,530 million
    *   2020: $5,039 million
    *   2021: $4,807 million
    This was negatively affected by declines in interest rates.
*   **Railroad:** The railroad segment's after-tax earnings increased by 16.1% in 2021 compared to 2020, and decreased 5.8% in 2020 compared to 2019 [7].
*   **Utilities and Energy:** This segment showed consistent growth. The increase in 2021 included higher earnings from the utilities and natural gas pipelines businesses [7].
*   **Manufacturing, Service, and Retailing:** Earnings in 2021 from these businesses increased 34.0% versus 2020 and declined 11.4% in 2020 versus 2019. Several businesses experienced higher costs due to global supply chain disruptions [10].
*    **Other** This segment includes after-tax goodwill and impairment charges, with approximately $9.8 billion of the charges in 2020 attributable to impairments from the acquisition of Precision Castparts in 2016 [5].

In summary, Berkshire Hathaway's net earnings showed significant fluctuation between 2019 and 2021, with a notable rebound in 2021, and the company actively repurchased its shares, spending $27.1 billion in 2021.

Here's an analysis of the key changes in Card Member loans and receivables from 2020 to 2021, along with a comparison to network volumes and Card Member spending:

**Card Member Loans:**

*   **Increase in Loan Balances**: Total Card Member loans increased from $73.4 billion in 2020 to $88.6 billion in 2021. This is a 21 percent increase [4].
*    **Credit Loss Reserves Decrease**: The ending balance of credit loss reserves for Card Member loans decreased significantly from $5,344 million in 2020 to $3,305 million in 2021 [5].
*   **Reserve Release**: Provisions for credit losses decreased, resulting in a net benefit due to a $2.5 billion reserve release, driven by improved portfolio quality and macroeconomic outlook [4].
*   The reserve for credit losses decreased in 2021 primarily due to an improved macroeconomic outlook [7].

**Card Member Receivables:**

*   **Increase in Receivable Balances**: Total Card Member receivables increased from $43.7 billion in 2020 to $53.6 billion in 2021.
*   **Credit Loss Reserves Decrease**: The ending balance of credit loss reserves for Card Member receivables also decreased from $267 million in 2020 to $64 million in 2021.
* The decreased of Credit Loss reserve is large part driven by improvement in unemployment rate projections [7].
    ![Changes in Card Member Loans and Receivables](image5)

**Network Volumes and Card Member Spending:**

*   **Network Volume Growth**: Worldwide network volumes increased by 24 percent in 2021, a strong recovery from the 18 percent decrease in 2020.
*    **Total Billed Business Growth**: The total billed business rose by 25 percent in 2021, compared to a 19 percent decline in 2020.
*   **Spending Growth Across Segments**: Both consumer and commercial billed businesses showed growth in 2021.

![Changes in Network Volumes and Spending](image4)

**Comparison and Key Takeaways:**

*   Although both Card Member loans and receivables increased from 2020 to 2021, there has a substantial reserve release in the same year [4].
*   The growth in Card Member loans (21 percent) was lower than the growth in billed business (25 percent) [4].
*   The growth in network volumes and Card Member spending indicates increased economic activity and consumer confidence, aligning with the overall positive trend in Card Member loans and receivables.
*    In 2020, the net cash was main driven by a decline in Card Member loan [6].

The document provides details on risk-based capital ratios and risk-weighted assets (RWA) calculations under both the Standardized and Advanced Approaches [4].

Specific details for 2019 are not provided in the text, But we can still offer some comparison base on the text and image.

For the year 2020:

*   **Capital Ratios:** Risk-based capital ratios are computed under both the Standardized and Advanced Approaches. These ratios apply to Common Equity Tier 1 capital, Tier 1 capital, and Total capital [1]. The Common Equity Tier 1 capital increased in 2020 primarily due to a net increase in Retained earnings and the impact of the E*TRADE acquisition [5].
*   **Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA):**
    *   **Credit Risk RWA:** Increased in 2020 under both approaches. This was driven by an increase in Derivatives exposures due to market volatility, an increase in Investment securities mainly due to the E*TRADE acquisition, increases in Lending commitments, and an increase in Equity investments [9].
    *   **Market Risk RWA:** Increased in 2020 under both approaches, primarily due to an increase in Regulatory VaR resulting from higher market volatility [6].
    *   **Operational Risk RWA:** Decreased in 2020 under the Advanced Approach due to a decline in the frequency and severity of litigation-related losses [2].

The calculation methods differ between the two approaches [4]:

*   **Standardized Approach:** Uses prescribed risk weights for calculating RWA.
*    **Advanced Approach:** Uses models to calculate exposure amounts and risk weights.
    RWA reflects both on- and off-balance sheet risk, as well as capital charges attributable to the risk of loss arising from various factor [3].

The types of risks considered include [7]:

*  **Credit risk**: The failure of a borrower to meet its financial obligations.
*    **Market risk**: Adverse change in market prices.
*    **Operational risk**: Inadequate or failed processes or systems.

![Risk-based capital ratio and RWA by approach.](image1)

The image indicates, under Standardized Approach, the Total risk-weighted assets is 2020 is 492,977, and under Advanced Approach is 459,729.

In summary, at the end of 2020, credit and market risk RWA increased under both Standardized and Advanced approaches, while operational risk RWA decreased under the Advanced Approach.

There is no information about the impact of changes in financial assumptions on actuarial gains and losses in Siemens Healthineers' defined benefit plans between the fiscal years 2020 and 2021 in the provided quotes.

However, the provided information clarifies how Siemens Healthineers determines the defined benefit obligation (DBO) [7]. The obligation from defined benefit plans reflects an actuarially calculated present value of the future benefit entitlement for services already rendered (defined benefit obligation, DBO) [7]. Actuarial valuations rely on key assumptions including discount rates, expected compensation increases, pension progression, and mortality rates [7]. Due to changing market, economic, and social conditions, the underlying actuarial assumptions may differ from actual developments [7]. A decline in the pension plans’ funded status due to an adverse development of plan assets or the defined benefit obligation is considered as a significant risk [5]. The funded status can be affected by changes in actuarial assumptions, primarily the discount rate, as well as movements in financial markets [5].

In 2020, an impairment loss of DKK 350 million was recognized, substantially all of which related to patents and licenses, compared to DKK 982 million in 2019 [3]. Of the 2020 impairment, DKK 350 million related to the Diabetes and Obesity care segment, and none related to Biopharm (compared to DKK 700 million in 2019) [3]. All the impairment loss in 2020 was recognized in research and development costs, whereas in 2019, DKK 529 million was in cost of goods sold and DKK 450 million in research and development costs [3]. The impairment in 2020 was due to Management's review of expectations for patents and licenses not yet in use, with no impairment related to marketable products identified [3].

Intangible assets not yet being amortized amounted to DKK 9,607 million in 2020 (DKK 3,380 million in 2019), primarily related to patents and licenses in research and development projects [4]. Impairment tests for these assets are based on Management’s projections and the anticipated net present value of estimated future cash flows from marketable products [4].
Property, plant, and equipment are measured at historical cost less accumulated depreciation and any impairment loss [8]. Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets [8].

The depreciation commences when the asset is available for use.
![The depreciation commences when the asset is available for use.](image1)

In summary, impairment losses decreased from DKK 982 million in 2019 to DKK 350 million in 2020, primarily affecting patents and licenses, with a shift in allocation between cost of goods sold and research and development costs.
